<p><b>Formula One</b>, commonly abbreviated as <b>F1</b>, is the highest class of international <a href="/wiki/Racing" title="Racing">racing</a> for <a href="/wiki/Open-wheel_single-seater" class="mw-redirect" title="Open-wheel single-seater">open-wheel single-seater</a> formula <a href="/wiki/Auto_racing" title="Auto racing">racing cars</a> sanctioned by the <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_de_l%27Automobile" title="Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile">Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile</a> (FIA). The <b>FIA Formula One World Championship</b> has been one of the world's premier forms of <a href="/wiki/Motorsport" title="Motorsport">motorsport</a> since its <a href="/wiki/1950_Formula_One_season" title="1950 Formula One season">inaugural running in 1950</a> and is often considered to be the pinnacle of motorsport. The word <i><a href="/wiki/Formula_racing" title="Formula racing">formula</a></i> in the name refers to <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_regulations" title="Formula One regulations">the set of rules</a> all participants' cars must follow. A Formula One season consists of a series of races, known as <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_Grands_Prix" title="List of Formula One Grands Prix">Grands Prix</a>. Grands Prix take place in multiple countries and continents on either purpose-built <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_circuits" title="List of Formula One circuits">circuits</a> or closed roads.
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Championship_points_scoring_systems" title="List of Formula One World Championship points scoring systems">point-system</a> is used at Grands Prix to determine two annual World Championships: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions">one for the drivers</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Constructors%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Constructors' Champions">one for the constructors</a>—now synonymous with teams. Each driver must hold a valid <a href="/wiki/FIA_Super_Licence" title="FIA Super Licence">Super Licence</a>, the highest class of racing licence the FIA issues, and the races must be held on <a href="/wiki/List_of_motor_racing_circuits_by_FIA_grade#Grade_One" title="List of motor racing circuits by FIA grade">Grade One tracks</a>, the highest grade rating the FIA issues for tracks.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Formula_One_car" title="Formula One car">Formula One cars</a> are the world's fastest regulated <a href="/wiki/Road_racing" title="Road racing">road-course</a> racing cars, owing to high cornering speeds achieved by generating large amounts of aerodynamic <a href="/wiki/Downforce" title="Downforce">downforce</a>, much of which is generated by front and rear wings, as well as <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_(cars)" title="Ground effect (cars)">underbody tunnels</a>. The cars depend on electronics, <a href="/wiki/Aerodynamics" title="Aerodynamics">aerodynamics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Car_suspension" title="Car suspension">suspension</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_tyres" title="Formula One tyres">tyres</a>. <a href="/wiki/Traction_control" class="mw-redirect" title="Traction control">Traction control</a>, <a href="/wiki/Launch_control_(automotive)" title="Launch control (automotive)">launch control</a>, <a href="/wiki/Automatic_shifting" class="mw-redirect" title="Automatic shifting">automatic shifting</a>, and other <a href="/wiki/Advanced_driver-assistance_systems" class="mw-redirect" title="Advanced driver-assistance systems">electronic driving aids</a> were first banned in <a href="/wiki/1994_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1994 Formula One World Championship">1994</a>. They were briefly reintroduced in <a href="/wiki/2001_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2001 Formula One World Championship">2001</a>, and have more recently been banned since <a href="/wiki/2004_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2004 Formula One World Championship">2004</a> and <a href="/wiki/2008_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2008 Formula One World Championship">2008</a>, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>1<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>With the average annual cost of running a team—designing, building, and maintaining cars, pay, transport—at approximately <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">£</a>220 million,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>2<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Formula One's financial and political battles are widely reported. The <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_Group" title="Formula One Group">Formula One Group</a> is owned by <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Media" title="Liberty Media">Liberty Media</a>, which acquired it in 2017 from private-equity firm <a href="/wiki/CVC_Capital_Partners" title="CVC Capital Partners">CVC Capital Partners</a> for <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">US$</a>8 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>3<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>4<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<meta property="mw:PageProp/toc">
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="History">History</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=1" title="Edit section: History"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Formula_One" title="History of Formula One">History of Formula One</a></div>
<p>Formula One originated from the <a href="/wiki/World_Manufacturers%27_Championship" title="World Manufacturers' Championship">World Manufacturers' Championship</a> (<a href="/wiki/1925_Grand_Prix_season" title="1925 Grand Prix season">1925</a>–<a href="/wiki/1930_Grand_Prix_season" title="1930 Grand Prix season">1930</a>) and <a href="/wiki/AIACR_European_Championship" title="AIACR European Championship">European Drivers' Championship</a> (<a href="/wiki/1931_Grand_Prix_season" title="1931 Grand Prix season">1931</a>–<a href="/wiki/1939_Grand_Prix_season" title="1939 Grand Prix season">1939</a>). The <a href="/wiki/Formula_racing" title="Formula racing"><i>formula</i></a> is a set of rules that all participants' cars must follow. Formula One was a formula agreed upon in <a href="/wiki/1946_Grand_Prix_season" title="1946 Grand Prix season">1946</a> to officially become effective in <a href="/wiki/1947_Grand_Prix_season" title="1947 Grand Prix season">1947</a>. The first Grand Prix in accordance with the new regulations was the <a href="/wiki/1946_Turin_Grand_Prix" title="1946 Turin Grand Prix">1946 Turin Grand Prix</a>, anticipating the formula's official start.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>5<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>6<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Before <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>, a number of Grand Prix racing organisations made suggestions for a new championship to replace the European Championship, but due to the suspension of racing during the conflict, the new International Formula for cars did not become formalised until 1946, to become effective in 1947. The new World Championship was instituted to commence in <a href="/wiki/1950_Formula_One_season" title="1950 Formula One season">1950</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>7<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The first world championship race, the <a href="/wiki/1950_British_Grand_Prix" title="1950 British Grand Prix">1950 British Grand Prix</a>, took place at <a href="/wiki/Silverstone_Circuit" title="Silverstone Circuit">Silverstone Circuit</a> in the United Kingdom on 13 May 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>8<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Giuseppe_Farina" title="Giuseppe Farina">Giuseppe Farina</a>, competing for <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_in_Formula_One" title="Alfa Romeo in Formula One">Alfa Romeo</a>, won the first Drivers' World Championship, narrowly defeating his teammate <a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Fangio" title="Juan Manuel Fangio">Juan Manuel Fangio</a>. Fangio won the championship in <a href="/wiki/1951_Formula_One_season" title="1951 Formula One season">1951</a>, <a href="/wiki/1954_Formula_One_season" title="1954 Formula One season">1954</a>, <a href="/wiki/1955_Formula_One_season" title="1955 Formula One season">1955</a>, <a href="/wiki/1956_Formula_One_season" title="1956 Formula One season">1956</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1957_Formula_One_season" title="1957 Formula One season">1957</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This set the record for the most World Championships won by a single driver, a record that stood for 46 years until <a href="/wiki/Michael_Schumacher" title="Michael Schumacher">Michael Schumacher</a> won his sixth championship in 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_9-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-9"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>9<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Alfa-Romeo-159-(1951).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Alfa-Romeo-159-%281951%29.jpg/220px-Alfa-Romeo-159-%281951%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Alfa-Romeo-159-%281951%29.jpg/330px-Alfa-Romeo-159-%281951%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Alfa-Romeo-159-%281951%29.jpg/440px-Alfa-Romeo-159-%281951%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="900"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Juan_Manuel_Fangio" title="Juan Manuel Fangio">Juan Manuel Fangio</a>'s <a href="/wiki/1951_Formula_One_season" title="1951 Formula One season">1951</a> title-winning <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_158/159_Alfetta" title="Alfa Romeo 158/159 Alfetta">Alfa Romeo 159</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>A Constructors' Championship was added in the <a href="/wiki/1958_Formula_One_season" title="1958 Formula One season">1958 season</a>. <a href="/wiki/Stirling_Moss" title="Stirling Moss">Stirling Moss</a>, despite often being regarded as one of the greatest Formula One drivers in the 1950s and 1960s, never won the Formula One championship.<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Between 1955 and 1961, Moss finished second in the championship four times and third the other three times.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Fangio won 24 of the 52 races he entered—still the record for the highest Formula One winning percentage by an individual driver.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>13<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> National championships existed in South Africa and the UK in the 1960s and 1970s. Promoters held non-championship Formula One events for many years. Due to the increasing cost of competition, the last of these was held in 1983.<sup id="cite_ref-LastnonchampF1_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LastnonchampF1-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>15<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>This era featured teams managed by road-car manufacturers, such as Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_in_Formula_One" title="Mercedes-Benz in Formula One">Mercedes-Benz</a> and <a href="/wiki/Maserati_in_motorsport" title="Maserati in motorsport">Maserati</a>. The first seasons featured prewar cars like Alfa Romeo's <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_158/159_Alfetta" title="Alfa Romeo 158/159 Alfetta">158</a>, which were <a href="/wiki/Front-engine,_rear-wheel-drive_layout" title="Front-engine, rear-wheel-drive layout">front-engined</a>, with narrow tyres and 1.5-litre supercharged or 4.5-litre naturally aspirated engines. The <a href="/wiki/1952_Formula_One_season" title="1952 Formula One season">1952</a> and <a href="/wiki/1953_Formula_One_season" title="1953 Formula One season">1953</a> seasons were run to <a href="/wiki/Formula_Two" title="Formula Two">Formula Two</a> regulations, for smaller, less powerful cars, due to concerns over the dearth of Formula One cars.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>16<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>17<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When a new Formula One formula for engines limited to 2.5 litres was reinstated for the 1954 world championship, <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> introduced its <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_W196" title="Mercedes-Benz W196">W196</a>, which featured things never seen on Formula One cars before, such as <a href="/wiki/Desmodromic_valve" title="Desmodromic valve">desmodromic valves</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fuel_injection" title="Fuel injection">fuel injection</a>, and enclosed streamlined bodywork. Mercedes drivers won the championship for the next two years, before the team withdrew from all motorsport competitions due to the <a href="/wiki/1955_Le_Mans_disaster" title="1955 Le Mans disaster">1955 Le Mans disaster</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>18<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>19<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Technological_developments">Technological developments</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=2" title="Edit section: Technological developments"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg/220px-MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="161" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg/330px-MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/be/MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg/440px-MossLotusClimax19610806.jpg 2x" data-file-width="680" data-file-height="497"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Stirling_Moss" title="Stirling Moss">Stirling Moss</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Lotus_18" title="Lotus 18">Lotus 18</a> at the <a href="/wiki/N%C3%BCrburgring" title="Nürburgring">Nürburgring</a> during <a href="/wiki/1961_Formula_One_season" title="1961 Formula One season">1961</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>The first major technological development in the sport was <a href="/wiki/Bugatti" title="Bugatti">Bugatti</a>'s introduction of <a href="/wiki/Mid-engine_design" title="Mid-engine design">mid-engined</a> cars. <a href="/wiki/Jack_Brabham" title="Jack Brabham">Jack Brabham</a>, the world champion in <a href="/wiki/1959_Formula_One_season" title="1959 Formula One season">1959</a>, <a href="/wiki/1960_Formula_One_season" title="1960 Formula One season">1960</a>, and <a href="/wiki/1966_Formula_One_season" title="1966 Formula One season">1966</a>, soon proved the mid-engine's superiority over all other engine positions. By <a href="/wiki/1961_Formula_One_season" title="1961 Formula One season">1961</a> all teams had switched to mid-engined cars. The <a href="/wiki/Ferguson_P99" title="Ferguson P99">Ferguson P99</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Four-wheel_drive" title="Four-wheel drive">four-wheel drive</a> design, was the last front-engined Formula One car to enter a world championship race. It entered the <a href="/wiki/1961_British_Grand_Prix" title="1961 British Grand Prix">1961 British Grand Prix</a>, the only front-engined car to compete that year.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>20<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During <a href="/wiki/1962_Formula_One_season" title="1962 Formula One season">1962</a>, <a href="/wiki/Team_Lotus" title="Team Lotus">Lotus</a> introduced a car with an aluminium-sheet <a href="/wiki/Monocoque" title="Monocoque">monocoque</a> chassis instead of the traditional <a href="/wiki/Space_frame" title="Space frame">space-frame</a> design. This proved to be the greatest technological breakthrough since the introduction of mid-engined cars.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/1968_Formula_One_season" title="1968 Formula One season">1968</a>, <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_sponsorship_liveries" title="Formula One sponsorship liveries">sponsorship was introduced to the sport</a>. <a href="/wiki/Team_Gunston" title="Team Gunston">Team Gunston</a> became the first team to run cigarette sponsorship on its <a href="/wiki/Brabham" title="Brabham">Brabham</a> cars, which <a href="/wiki/Privateer_(motorsport)" title="Privateer (motorsport)">privately entered</a> in orange, brown and gold colours of <a href="/wiki/Gunston_(cigarette)" title="Gunston (cigarette)">Gunston</a> cigarettes in the <a href="/wiki/1968_South_African_Grand_Prix" title="1968 South African Grand Prix">1968 South African Grand Prix</a> on 1 January 1968.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>21<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Five months later, the first <a href="/wiki/Factory-backed" title="Factory-backed">works team</a>, Lotus, initially using the <a href="/wiki/British_racing_green" title="British racing green">British racing green</a>, followed this example when it entered <a href="/wiki/Lotus_49" title="Lotus 49">its cars</a> painted in the red, gold, and white colours of the <a href="/wiki/Imperial_Tobacco" class="mw-redirect" title="Imperial Tobacco">Imperial Tobacco</a>'s Gold Leaf livery at the <a href="/wiki/1968_Spanish_Grand_Prix" title="1968 Spanish Grand Prix">1968 Spanish Grand Prix</a>.
</p><p>Aerodynamic <a href="/wiki/Downforce" title="Downforce">downforce</a> slowly gained importance in car design with the appearance of <a href="/wiki/Airfoil" title="Airfoil">aerofoils</a> during the 1968 season. The wings were introduced by Lotus's owner <a href="/wiki/Colin_Chapman" title="Colin Chapman">Colin Chapman</a> who installed modest front wings and a rear spoiler on his <a href="/wiki/Lotus_49" title="Lotus 49">Lotus 49</a>B at the <a href="/wiki/1968_Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="1968 Monaco Grand Prix">1968 Monaco Grand Prix</a>. In the late 1970s, Lotus introduced <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_in_cars" class="mw-redirect" title="Ground effect in cars">ground-effect</a> aerodynamics, previously used on <a href="/wiki/Jim_Hall_(race_car_driver)" class="mw-redirect" title="Jim Hall (race car driver)">Jim Hall</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Chaparral_Cars" title="Chaparral Cars">Chaparral 2J</a> in 1970, that provided enormous downforce and greatly increased cornering speeds. The aerodynamic forces pressing the cars to the track were up to five times the car's weight. As a result, extremely stiff springs were needed to maintain a constant <a href="/wiki/Ride_height" title="Ride height">ride height</a>, leaving the suspension virtually solid. This meant that the drivers depended entirely on the tyres for any small amount of cushioning of the car and driver from irregularities of the road surface.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>22<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Big_business">Big business</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=3" title="Edit section: Big business"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Beginning in the 1970s, <a href="/wiki/Bernie_Ecclestone" title="Bernie Ecclestone">Bernie Ecclestone</a> rearranged the management of Formula One's commercial rights; he is widely credited with transforming the sport into the multibillion-dollar business it now is.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian280397_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian280397-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mrformula_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mrformula-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When Ecclestone bought the Brabham team during 1971, he gained a seat on the <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_Constructors%27_Association" title="Formula One Constructors' Association">Formula One Constructors' Association</a>, and in 1978, he became its president.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>25<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Previously, the circuit owners controlled the income of the teams and negotiated with each individually; Ecclestone persuaded the teams to "hunt as a pack" through FOCA.<sup id="cite_ref-mrformula_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mrformula-24"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>24<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He offered Formula One to circuit owners as a package they could take or leave. In return for the package, almost all that was required was to surrender trackside advertising.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian280397_23-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian280397-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The formation of the <a href="/wiki/F%C3%A9d%C3%A9ration_Internationale_du_Sport_Automobile" class="mw-redirect" title="Fédération Internationale du Sport Automobile">Fédération Internationale du Sport Automobile</a> (FISA) in 1979 set off the <a href="/wiki/FISA%E2%80%93FOCA_war" title="FISA–FOCA war">FISA–FOCA war</a>, during which FISA and its president <a href="/wiki/Jean-Marie_Balestre" title="Jean-Marie Balestre">Jean-Marie Balestre</a> argued repeatedly with FOCA over television revenues and technical regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>The Guardian</i> said that Ecclestone and <a href="/wiki/Max_Mosley" title="Max Mosley">Max Mosley</a> "used [FOCA] to wage a guerrilla war with a very long-term aim in view". FOCA threatened to establish a rival series and boycotted a Grand Prix, and FISA withdrew its sanction from races.<sup id="cite_ref-guardian280397_23-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-guardian280397-23"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>23<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The result was the 1981 <a href="/wiki/Concorde_Agreement" title="Concorde Agreement">Concorde Agreement</a>, which guaranteed technical stability, as teams were to be given reasonable notice of new regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>27<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although FISA asserted its right to the TV revenues, it gave FOCA the administration of those rights.<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>FISA imposed a ban on <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_(cars)" title="Ground effect (cars)">ground-effect aerodynamics</a> during <a href="/wiki/1983_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1983 Formula One World Championship">1983</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>29<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> But by then, <a href="/wiki/Turbocharger" title="Turbocharger">turbocharged</a> engines, which <a href="/wiki/Renault_in_Formula_One" title="Renault in Formula One">Renault</a> had pioneered in <a href="/wiki/1977_Formula_One_season" title="1977 Formula One season">1977</a>, were producing over 520 kW (700 bhp) and were essential to be competitive. By <a href="/wiki/1986_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1986 Formula One World Championship">1986</a>, a BMW turbocharged engine achieved a flash reading of 5.5 bar (80 psi) pressure, estimated<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (January 2023)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> to be over 970 kW (1,300 bhp) in qualifying for the <a href="/wiki/1986_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="1986 Italian Grand Prix">Italian Grand Prix</a>. The next year, power in race trim reached around 820 kW (1,100 bhp), with boost pressure limited to only 4.0 bar.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>30<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These cars were the most powerful <a href="/wiki/Open-wheel_car" title="Open-wheel car">open-wheel</a> circuit racing cars ever. To reduce engine power output and thus speeds, the FIA limited fuel tank capacity in <a href="/wiki/1984_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1984 Formula One World Championship">1984</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Boost_(automotive_engineering)" class="mw-redirect" title="Boost (automotive engineering)">boost</a> pressures in <a href="/wiki/1988_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1988 Formula One World Championship">1988</a>, before banning turbocharged engines completely in <a href="/wiki/1989_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1989 Formula One World Championship">1989</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>31<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The development of electronic driver aids began in the 1980s. Lotus began to develop a system of <a href="/wiki/Active_suspension" title="Active suspension">active suspension</a>, which first appeared during 1983 on the <a href="/wiki/Lotus_92" title="Lotus 92">Lotus 92</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>32<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> By 1987, this system had been perfected and was driven to victory by <a href="/wiki/Ayrton_Senna" title="Ayrton Senna">Ayrton Senna</a> in the <a href="/wiki/1987_Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="1987 Monaco Grand Prix">Monaco Grand Prix</a> that year. In the early 1990s, other teams followed suit and <a href="/wiki/Semi-automatic_transmission" title="Semi-automatic transmission">semi-automatic gearboxes</a> and <a href="/wiki/Traction_control_system" title="Traction control system">traction control</a> were a natural progression. The FIA, due to complaints that technology was determining races' outcomes more than driver skill, banned many such aids for the <a href="/wiki/1994_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1994 Formula One World Championship">1994</a> season. This resulted in cars that previously depended on electronic aids becoming very "twitchy" and difficult to drive. Observers felt the ban on driver aids was in name only, as they "proved difficult to police effectively".<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>33<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The teams signed a second <a href="/wiki/Concorde_Agreement" title="Concorde Agreement">Concorde Agreement</a> in 1992 and a third in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>34<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg/220px-1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="144" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg/330px-1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/70/1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg/440px-1985_European_GP_Stefan_Johansson_01.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3256" data-file-height="2136"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Stefan_Johansson" title="Stefan Johansson">Stefan Johansson</a> driving for <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1985_European_Grand_Prix" title="1985 European Grand Prix">1985 European Grand Prix</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>On the track, the <a href="/wiki/McLaren" title="McLaren">McLaren</a> and <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">Williams</a> teams dominated the 1980s and 1990s. Brabham was also competitive during the early 1980s, winning two Drivers' Championships with <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Piquet" title="Nelson Piquet">Nelson Piquet</a>. Powered by <a href="/wiki/Porsche_in_Formula_One" class="mw-redirect" title="Porsche in Formula One">Porsche</a>, <a href="/wiki/Honda_Racing_F1" class="mw-redirect" title="Honda Racing F1">Honda</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mercedes_AMG_High_Performance_Powertrains" title="Mercedes AMG High Performance Powertrains">Mercedes-Benz</a>, McLaren won 16 championships (seven constructors' and nine drivers') in that period, while Williams used engines from <a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a>, Honda, and <a href="/wiki/Renault_in_Formula_One" title="Renault in Formula One">Renault</a> to also win 16 titles (nine constructors' and seven drivers'). The rivalry between racers <a href="/wiki/Ayrton_Senna" title="Ayrton Senna">Ayrton Senna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alain_Prost" title="Alain Prost">Alain Prost</a> became F1's central focus during <a href="/wiki/1988_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1988 Formula One World Championship">1988</a> and continued until Prost retired at the end of <a href="/wiki/1993_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1993 Formula One World Championship">1993</a>. Senna <a href="/wiki/Death_of_Ayrton_Senna" title="Death of Ayrton Senna">died</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1994_San_Marino_Grand_Prix" title="1994 San Marino Grand Prix">1994 San Marino Grand Prix</a> after crashing into a wall on the exit of the notorious curve <a href="/wiki/Tamburello_(corner)" class="mw-redirect" title="Tamburello (corner)">Tamburello</a>. The FIA worked to improve the sport's safety standards since that weekend, during which <a href="/wiki/Roland_Ratzenberger" title="Roland Ratzenberger">Roland Ratzenberger</a> also died in an accident during Saturday qualifying. No driver died of injuries sustained on the track at the wheel of a Formula One car for 20 years until the <a href="/wiki/2014_Japanese_Grand_Prix" title="2014 Japanese Grand Prix">2014 Japanese Grand Prix</a>, where <a href="/wiki/Jules_Bianchi" title="Jules Bianchi">Jules Bianchi</a> collided with a recovery vehicle after <a href="/wiki/Aquaplaning" title="Aquaplaning">aquaplaning</a> off the circuit, dying nine months later from his injuries. Since 1994, three track marshals have died, one at the <a href="/wiki/2000_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="2000 Italian Grand Prix">2000 Italian Grand Prix</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-MarshallDeaths2000s_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarshallDeaths2000s-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> one at the <a href="/wiki/2001_Australian_Grand_Prix" title="2001 Australian Grand Prix">2001 Australian Grand Prix</a><sup id="cite_ref-MarshallDeaths2000s_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MarshallDeaths2000s-35"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>35<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and one at the <a href="/wiki/2013_Canadian_Grand_Prix" title="2013 Canadian Grand Prix">2013 Canadian Grand Prix</a>.
</p><p>Since Senna's and Ratzenberger's deaths, the FIA has used safety as a reason to impose rule changes that otherwise, under the Concorde Agreement, would have had to be agreed upon by all the teams—most notably the changes introduced for <a href="/wiki/1998_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1998 Formula One World Championship">1998</a>. This so-called 'narrow track' era resulted in cars with smaller rear tyres, a narrower track overall, and the introduction of grooved tyres to reduce mechanical grip. The objective was to reduce cornering speeds and produce racing similar to rainy conditions by enforcing a smaller <a href="/wiki/Contact_patch" title="Contact patch">contact patch</a> between tyre and track. According to the FIA, this was to reduce cornering speeds in the interest of safety.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>36<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg/220px-Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="143" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg/330px-Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg/440px-Damon_Hill_1995-2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3467" data-file-height="2255"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Damon_Hill" title="Damon Hill">Damon Hill</a> driving for <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">Williams</a> at the <a href="/wiki/1995_Canadian_Grand_Prix" title="1995 Canadian Grand Prix">1995 Canadian Grand Prix</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Results were mixed, as the lack of mechanical grip resulted in the more ingenious designers clawing back the deficit with aerodynamic grip. This resulted in pushing more force onto the tyres through wings and aerodynamic devices, which in turn resulted in less overtaking, as these devices tended to make the wake behind the car turbulent or 'dirty'. This prevented other cars from following closely due to their dependence on 'clean' air to make the car stick to the track. The grooved tyres also had the unfortunate side effect of initially being of a harder compound to be able to hold the grooved tread blocks, which resulted in spectacular accidents in times of aerodynamic grip failure, as the harder compound could not grip the track as well.
</p><p>Drivers from <a href="/wiki/McLaren" title="McLaren">McLaren</a>, <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">Williams</a>, <a href="/wiki/Renault_in_Formula_One" title="Renault in Formula One">Renault</a> (formerly <a href="/wiki/Benetton_Formula" title="Benetton Formula">Benetton</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari</a>, dubbed the "Big Four", won every <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions">World Championship</a> from <a href="/wiki/1984_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1984 Formula One World Championship">1984</a> to <a href="/wiki/2008_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2008 Formula One World Championship">2008</a>. The teams won every <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Constructors%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Constructors' Champions">Constructors' Championship</a> from <a href="/wiki/1979_Formula_One_season" title="1979 Formula One season">1979</a> to <a href="/wiki/2008_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2008 Formula One World Championship">2008</a>, as well as placing themselves as the top four teams in the Constructors' Championship in every season between <a href="/wiki/1989_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1989 Formula One World Championship">1989</a> and <a href="/wiki/1997_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1997 Formula One World Championship">1997</a>, and winning every race but one (the <a href="/wiki/1996_Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="1996 Monaco Grand Prix">1996 Monaco Grand Prix</a>) between <a href="/wiki/1988_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1988 Formula One World Championship">1988</a> and <a href="/wiki/1997_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1997 Formula One World Championship">1997</a>. Due to the technological advances of the 1990s, the cost of competing in Formula One increased dramatically, thus increasing financial burdens. This, combined with the dominance of four teams (largely funded by big car manufacturers such as Mercedes-Benz), caused the poorer independent teams to struggle not only to remain competitive but to stay in business. This effectively forced several teams to withdraw.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Manufacturers'_return"><span id="Manufacturers.27_return"></span>Manufacturers' return</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=4" title="Edit section: Manufacturers' return"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Michael_Schumacher,_Ferrari_F2001_(8968595731)_(cropped).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Michael_Schumacher%2C_Ferrari_F2001_%288968595731%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/220px-Michael_Schumacher%2C_Ferrari_F2001_%288968595731%29_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="114" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Michael_Schumacher%2C_Ferrari_F2001_%288968595731%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/330px-Michael_Schumacher%2C_Ferrari_F2001_%288968595731%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Michael_Schumacher%2C_Ferrari_F2001_%288968595731%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/440px-Michael_Schumacher%2C_Ferrari_F2001_%288968595731%29_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1240" data-file-height="640"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Michael_Schumacher" title="Michael Schumacher">Michael Schumacher</a> (pictured here in <a href="/wiki/2001_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2001 Formula One World Championship">2001</a>) won five consecutive titles with <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari</a>.</figcaption></figure><p> Michael Schumacher and Ferrari won five consecutive Drivers' Championships (2000–2004) and six consecutive Constructors' Championships (1999–2004). Schumacher set many new records, including those for Grand Prix wins (91, since beaten by <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton" title="Lewis Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a>), wins in a season (13, since beaten by <a href="/wiki/Max_Verstappen" title="Max Verstappen">Max Verstappen</a>), and most Drivers' Championships (seven, tied with Lewis Hamilton as of 2021).<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>37<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Schumacher's championship streak ended on 25 September 2005, when Renault driver <a href="/wiki/Fernando_Alonso" title="Fernando Alonso">Fernando Alonso</a> became Formula One's youngest champion at that time (until Lewis Hamilton in <a href="/wiki/2008_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2008 Formula One World Championship">2008</a> and followed by <a href="/wiki/Sebastian_Vettel" title="Sebastian Vettel">Sebastian Vettel</a> in <a href="/wiki/2010_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2010 Formula One World Championship">2010</a>). During 2006, Renault and Alonso won both titles again. Schumacher retired at the end of 2006 after 16 years in Formula One, but came out of retirement for the 2010 season, racing for the newly formed Mercedes works team, following the rebrand of <a href="/wiki/Brawn_GP" title="Brawn GP">Brawn GP</a>.
</p><p>During this period, FIA frequently changed the championship rules with the intention of improving the on-track action and cutting costs.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>38<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Team_orders" title="Team orders">Team orders</a>, legal since the championship started during 1950, were banned during 2002, after several incidents in which teams openly manipulated race results, generating negative publicity, most famously by Ferrari at the <a href="/wiki/2002_Austrian_Grand_Prix" title="2002 Austrian Grand Prix">2002 Austrian Grand Prix</a>. Other changes included the qualifying format, the point-scoring system, the technical regulations, and rules specifying how long engines and tyres must last. A 'tyre war' between suppliers <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bridgestone" title="Bridgestone">Bridgestone</a> saw lap times fall, although, at the <a href="/wiki/2005_United_States_Grand_Prix" title="2005 United States Grand Prix">2005 United States Grand Prix</a> at Indianapolis, seven out of ten teams did not race when their Michelin tyres were deemed unsafe for use, leading to Bridgestone becoming the sole tyre supplier to Formula One for the 2007 season by default. On 20 December 2007 Bridgestone signed a contract that officially made it the exclusive tyre supplier for the next three seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>39<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During 2006, Max Mosley outlined a 'green' future for Formula One, in which efficient use of energy would be an important factor.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>40<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Starting in 2000, with Ford's purchase of <a href="/wiki/Stewart_Grand_Prix" title="Stewart Grand Prix">Stewart Grand Prix</a> to form the <a href="/wiki/Jaguar_Racing" title="Jaguar Racing">Jaguar Racing</a> team, new manufacturer-owned teams entered Formula One for the first time since Alfa Romeo's and Renault's departures in 1985. By 2006, the manufacturer teams—Renault, <a href="/wiki/BMW_Sauber" class="mw-redirect" title="BMW Sauber">BMW</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toyota_F1" class="mw-redirect" title="Toyota F1">Toyota</a>, Honda, and Ferrari—dominated the championship, taking five of the first six places in the Constructors' Championship. The exception was McLaren, which at the time was part-owned by Mercedes-Benz. Through the <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_Manufacturers_Association" title="Grand Prix Manufacturers Association">Grand Prix Manufacturers Association</a> (GPMA), the manufacturers negotiated a larger share of Formula One's commercial profit and a greater say in the running of the sport.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>41<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Manufacturers'_decline_and_return_of_the_privateers"><span id="Manufacturers.27_decline_and_return_of_the_privateers"></span>Manufacturers' decline and return of the privateers</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=5" title="Edit section: Manufacturers' decline and return of the privateers"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In 2008 and 2009, <a href="/wiki/Honda_in_Formula_One" title="Honda in Formula One">Honda</a>, <a href="/wiki/BMW_in_Formula_One" title="BMW in Formula One">BMW</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Racing_(Formula_One_team)" class="mw-redirect" title="Toyota Racing (Formula One team)">Toyota</a> all withdrew from Formula One racing within a year, blaming the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">economic recession</a>. This resulted in the end of manufacturer dominance of the sport. The Honda F1 team went through a management buyout to become <a href="/wiki/Brawn_GP" title="Brawn GP">Brawn GP</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Ross_Brawn" title="Ross Brawn">Ross Brawn</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nick_Fry" title="Nick Fry">Nick Fry</a> running and owning the majority of the organisation. Brawn GP laid off hundreds of employees, but won the year's world championships. BMW F1 was bought out by the original founder of the team, <a href="/wiki/Peter_Sauber" title="Peter Sauber">Peter Sauber</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Lotus_F1_Team" class="mw-redirect" title="Lotus F1 Team">Lotus F1 Team</a><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>42<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> was another, formerly manufacturer-owned team that reverted to "privateer" ownership, together with the buy-out of the <a href="/wiki/Renault_in_Formula_One" title="Renault in Formula One">Renault</a> team by <a href="/wiki/Genii_Capital" title="Genii Capital">Genii Capital</a> investors. But a link with its previous owners still survived, with its car continuing to be powered by a <a href="/wiki/Renault_in_Formula_One" title="Renault in Formula One">Renault</a> engine until 2014.
</p>
