class="thumbcaption">The three teams that debuted in 2010 all disappeared within seven years of their debuts.</div></div></div></div></div>
<p>McLaren also announced that it was to reacquire the shares in its team from Mercedes-Benz (McLaren's partnership with Mercedes was reported to have started to sour with the <a href="/wiki/McLaren_Mercedes_SLR" class="mw-redirect" title="McLaren Mercedes SLR">McLaren Mercedes SLR</a> road car project and tough F1 championships, which included McLaren being found guilty of <a href="/wiki/2007_Formula_One_espionage_controversy" title="2007 Formula One espionage controversy">spying on Ferrari</a>). Hence, during the 2010 season, Mercedes-Benz reentered the sport as a manufacturer after it purchased <a href="/wiki/Brawn_GP" title="Brawn GP">Brawn GP</a> and split with McLaren after 15 seasons with the team.
</p><p>During the <a href="/wiki/2009_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2009 Formula One World Championship">2009</a> season, Formula One was gripped by the <a href="/wiki/FIA%E2%80%93FOTA_dispute" title="FIA–FOTA dispute">FIA–FOTA dispute</a>. FIA President Max Mosley proposed numerous cost-cutting measures for the next season, including an optional budget cap for the teams;<sup id="cite_ref-budgetcap_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-budgetcap-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> teams electing to take the budget cap would be granted greater technical freedom, adjustable front and rear wings, and an engine not subject to a <a href="/wiki/Rev_limiter" title="Rev limiter">rev limiter</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-budgetcap_43-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-budgetcap-43"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>43<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_Teams_Association" title="Formula One Teams Association">Formula One Teams Association</a> (FOTA) believed that allowing some teams to have such technical freedom would have created a 'two-tier' championship, and thus requested urgent talks with the FIA. But talks broke down and FOTA teams announced, with the exception of Williams and <a href="/wiki/Force_India" title="Force India">Force India</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-compromise_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-compromise-44"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>44<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-timeline_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timeline-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> that 'they had no choice' but to form a <a href="/wiki/Grand_Prix_World_Championship" title="Grand Prix World Championship">breakaway championship series</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-timeline_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-timeline-45"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>45<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg/220px-Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg/330px-Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg/440px-Bernie_Ecclestone_2012_Bahrain.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1000" data-file-height="665"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Bernie_Ecclestone" title="Bernie Ecclestone">Bernie Ecclestone</a>, the former Chief executive of the Formula One Group</figcaption></figure>
<p>On 24 June, Formula One's governing body and the teams reached an agreement to prevent a breakaway series. It was agreed teams must cut spending to the level of the early 1990s within two years; exact figures were not specified,<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>46<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and Max Mosley agreed he would not stand for reelection to the FIA presidency in October.<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-47"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>47<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Following further disagreements, after Mosley suggested he would stand for reelection,<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>48<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> FOTA made it clear that breakaway plans were still being pursued. On 8 July, FOTA issued a press release stating it had been informed it was not entered for the 2010 season,<sup id="cite_ref-FOTA_Press_Release_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOTA_Press_Release-49"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>49<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and an FIA press release said the FOTA representatives had walked out of the meeting.<sup id="cite_ref-FIA_Press_Release_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIA_Press_Release-50"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>50<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 1 August, it was announced FIA and FOTA had signed a new Concorde Agreement, bringing an end to the crisis and securing the sport's future until 2012.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>51<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>To compensate for the loss of manufacturer teams, four new teams were accepted entry into the 2010 season ahead of a much anticipated 'cost-cap'. Entrants included a reborn <a href="/wiki/Team_Lotus_(2010-11)" class="mw-redirect" title="Team Lotus (2010-11)">Team Lotus</a>—led by a Malaysian consortium including <a href="/wiki/Tony_Fernandes" title="Tony Fernandes">Tony Fernandes</a>, the boss of <a href="/wiki/Air_Asia" class="mw-redirect" title="Air Asia">Air Asia</a>; <a href="/wiki/HRT_F1_Team" class="mw-redirect" title="HRT F1 Team">Hispania Racing</a>—the first Spanish Formula One team; and <a href="/wiki/Virgin_Racing" title="Virgin Racing">Virgin Racing</a>—<a href="/wiki/Richard_Branson" title="Richard Branson">Richard Branson</a>'s entry into the series following a successful partnership with Brawn the year before. They were also joined by the <a href="/wiki/US_F1_Team" title="US F1 Team">US F1 Team</a>, which planned to run out of the United States as the only non-European-based team in the sport. Financial issues befell the squad before they even made the grid. Despite the entry of these new teams, the proposed cost-cap was repealed and these teams—which did not have the budgets of the midfield and top-order teams—ran around at the back of the field until they collapsed; HRT in 2012, Caterham (formerly Lotus) in 2014 and Manor (formerly Virgin, then Marussia), having survived falling into administration in 2014, at the end of 2016.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Hybrid_era">Hybrid era</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=6" title="Edit section: Hybrid era"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><p>
A major rule shakeup in <a href="/wiki/2014_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2014 Formula One World Championship">2014</a> saw the 2.4-litre naturally aspirated V8 engines replaced by 1.6-litre turbocharged hybrid power units. This prompted Honda to return to the sport in 2015 as the championship's fourth power unit manufacturer. Mercedes emerged as the dominant force after the rule shakeup, with <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton" title="Lewis Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a> winning the championship closely followed by his main rival and teammate, <a href="/wiki/Nico_Rosberg" title="Nico Rosberg">Nico Rosberg</a>, with the team winning 16 out of the 19 races that season. The team continued this form in the next two seasons, again winning 16 races in <a href="/wiki/2015_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2015 Formula One World Championship">2015</a> before taking a record 19 wins in <a href="/wiki/2016_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2016 Formula One World Championship">2016</a>, with Hamilton claiming the title in the former year and Rosberg winning it in the latter by five points. The 2016 season also saw a new team, <a href="/wiki/Haas_F1_Team" title="Haas F1 Team">Haas</a>, join the grid, while <a href="/wiki/Max_Verstappen" title="Max Verstappen">Max Verstappen</a> became the youngest-ever race winner at age 18 in <a href="/wiki/Spanish_Grand_Prix" title="Spanish Grand Prix">Spain</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>52<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg/220px-FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg/330px-FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg/440px-FIA_F1_Austria_2018_Nr._44_Hamilton.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4086" data-file-height="2298"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz_in_Formula_One" title="Mercedes-Benz in Formula One">Mercedes</a> won eight consecutive constructors' titles and <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton" title="Lewis Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a> won six drivers' titles during the beginning of the hybrid era.</figcaption></figure>
<p>After revised aerodynamic regulations were introduced, the <a href="/wiki/2017_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2017 Formula One World Championship">2017</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2018 Formula One World Championship">2018</a> seasons featured a title battle between Mercedes and Ferrari.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>53<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>54<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>55<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>56<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Mercedes ultimately won the titles with multiple races to spare and continued to dominate in the next two years,<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>57<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> eventually winning seven consecutive Drivers' Championships from 2014 to <a href="/wiki/2020_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2020 Formula One World Championship">2020</a> and eight consecutive Constructors' titles from 2014 to 2021. During this eight-year period between 2014 and 2021, a Mercedes driver won 111 of the 160 races,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>58<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with Hamilton winning 81 of these and taking six Drivers' Championships during this period to equal Schumacher's record of seven titles.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>59<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>60<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>61<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/2021_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2021 Formula One World Championship">2021</a>, the Honda-powered Red Bull team began to seriously challenge Mercedes, with Verstappen beating Hamilton to the Drivers' Championship after a season-long battle that saw the pair exchange the championship lead multiple times.
</p><p>This era has seen an increase in car manufacturer presence in the sport. After Honda's return as an engine manufacturer in 2015, Renault came back as a team in 2016 after buying back the <a href="/wiki/Lotus_F1" title="Lotus F1">Lotus F1</a> team. In 2018, <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin" title="Aston Martin">Aston Martin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo" title="Alfa Romeo">Alfa Romeo</a> became Red Bull and Sauber's title sponsors, respectively. Sauber was rebranded as <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_Racing" class="mw-redirect" title="Alfa Romeo Racing">Alfa Romeo Racing</a> for the 2019 season, while <a href="/wiki/Racing_Point_F1_Team" title="Racing Point F1 Team">Racing Point</a> part-owner <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Stroll" title="Lawrence Stroll">Lawrence Stroll</a> bought a stake in Aston Martin to rebrand the Racing Point team as Aston Martin for 2021. In August 2020, all ten F1 teams signed a new Concorde Agreement committing them to the sport until 2025, including a $145 million budget cap for car development to support equal competition and sustainable development.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>62<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>63<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> forced the sport to adapt to budgetary and logistical limitations. A significant overhaul of the technical regulations intended to be introduced in the 2021 season was pushed back to 2022,<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>64<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> with constructors instead using their 2020 chassis for two seasons and a token system limiting which parts could be modified introduced.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>65<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The start of the <a href="/wiki/2020_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2020 Formula One World Championship">2020</a> season was delayed by several months,<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>66<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and both it and <a href="/wiki/2021_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2021 Formula One World Championship">2021</a> seasons were subject to several postponements, cancellations, and rescheduling of races due to <a href="/wiki/Travel_restrictions_related_to_the_COVID-19_pandemic" class="mw-redirect" title="Travel restrictions related to the COVID-19 pandemic">shifting restrictions</a> on international travel. Many races took place <a href="/wiki/Behind_closed_doors_(sport)" title="Behind closed doors (sport)">behind closed doors</a> and with only essential personnel present to maintain <a href="/wiki/Social_distancing" title="Social distancing">social distancing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>67<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2022, the F1 governing body announced a major rule and car design change intended to promote closer racing through the use of <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_(cars)" title="Ground effect (cars)">ground effects</a>, new aerodynamics, larger wheels with low-profile tyres, and redesigned nose and wing regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>68<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>69<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing" title="Red Bull Racing">Red Bull</a> emerged as the dominant force after the rule shakeup. The <a href="/wiki/2022_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2022 Formula One World Championship">2022</a> and <a href="/wiki/2023_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2023 Formula One World Championship">2023</a> Constructors' and Drivers' Championships were won by Red Bull and Verstappen, with multiple races to spare.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>70<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>71<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>72<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>73<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In 2023 the FIA opened applications for new teams to enter Formula 1 in the then near future.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>74<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Of the teams that applied, only <a href="/wiki/Andretti_Global" title="Andretti Global">Andretti</a> were approved by the FIA, with them then being rejected by <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_Group" title="Formula One Group">Formula One Management</a>, though they have launched an appeal.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>75<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>76<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In early 2024, the Formula One landscape underwent a significant change in the sphere of team sponsorships and collaborations. Having competed for five seasons under the <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_in_Formula_One" title="Alfa Romeo in Formula One">Alfa Romeo</a> name, Sauber introduced a title partnership with the online casino <a href="/wiki/Stake.com" class="mw-redirect" title="Stake.com">Stake.com</a>, resulting in the team's new identity as <a href="/wiki/Sauber_Motorsport" title="Sauber Motorsport">Stake F1 Team Kick Sauber</a>. Sauber will hold Stake's sponsorship name until the end of 2025, after which it will become the Audi works team for the 2026 season onwards.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>77<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>78<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_AlphaTauri" title="Scuderia AlphaTauri">Scuderia AlphaTauri</a>, Red Bull's junior team, dropped its name and took on sponsors from Hugo Boss and Cash App, becoming <a href="/wiki/Visa_Inc." title="Visa Inc.">Visa</a> <a href="/wiki/Cash_App" title="Cash App">Cash App</a> RB, or VCARB for 2024. Also in 2024, Formula One announced partnerships with <a href="/wiki/Mattel" title="Mattel">Mattel</a> to release <a href="/wiki/Hot_Wheels" title="Hot Wheels">Hot Wheels</a> die-cast cars,<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>79<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and with <a href="/wiki/Lego" title="Lego">Lego</a>, with the first new sets releasing in 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>80<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Previously, Lego sets based on Formula One cars had been released in 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>81<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The regulations governing Formula One are set to be revised for the 2026 season, with big changes planned to help encourage closer and more competitive racing.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>82<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> 
Changes include: 
</p>
<ul><li>Move to fully sustainable fuels,</li>
<li>Reduction in width and length for closer racing</li>
<li>new Front and Rear wing regulations</li>
<li>Electric Motor</li>
<li>MGU-K (Motor Generator Unit – Kinetic) power increased from 120 kW to 350 kW</li>
<li>More stringent safety requirements</li>
<li>Tighter budget caps</li></ul>
<p>In November 2024, <a href="/wiki/General_Motors" title="General Motors">General Motors</a> reached an agreement to enter Formula 1 in 2026 with its <a href="/wiki/Cadillac" title="Cadillac">Cadillac</a> brand.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>83<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Racing_and_strategy">Racing and strategy</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=7" title="Edit section: Racing and strategy"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_racing" title="Formula One racing">Formula One racing</a>, <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_tyres" title="Formula One tyres">Formula One tyres</a>, <a href="/wiki/Racing_flags" title="Racing flags">Racing flags</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_regulations" title="Formula One regulations">Formula One regulations</a></div><p>A Formula One Grand Prix event spans a weekend. It typically begins with two free practice sessions on Friday, and one free practice session on Saturday. Additional drivers (commonly known as <a href="/wiki/Third_driver" class="mw-redirect" title="Third driver">third drivers</a>) are allowed to run on Fridays, but only two cars may be used per team, requiring a race driver to give up their seat. A qualifying session is held after the last free practice session. This session determines the starting order for the race on Sunday.<sup id="cite_ref-QDetail2_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-QDetail2-84"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>84<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-DriveChang_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DriveChang-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Tyre_rules">Tyre rules</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=8" title="Edit section: Tyre rules"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Pirelli_Tire_Range_(52849596009).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Pirelli_Tire_Range_%2852849596009%29.jpg/220px-Pirelli_Tire_Range_%2852849596009%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Pirelli_Tire_Range_%2852849596009%29.jpg/330px-Pirelli_Tire_Range_%2852849596009%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Pirelli_Tire_Range_%2852849596009%29.jpg/440px-Pirelli_Tire_Range_%2852849596009%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4032" data-file-height="2268"></a><figcaption>The 2023 Pirelli tyres include (from left to right) the three slick compound tyres: soft (red), medium (yellow), and hard (white) – and the two wet-weather tyre compounds: intermediate (green), and full-wet (blue).</figcaption></figure>
<p>Each driver may use no more than thirteen sets of dry-weather tyres, four sets of intermediate tyres, and three sets of wet-weather tyres during a race weekend.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>86<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Qualifying">Qualifying</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=9" title="Edit section: Qualifying"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>For much of the sport's history, qualifying sessions differed little from practice sessions; drivers would have one or more sessions in which to set their fastest time, with the grid order determined by each driver's best single lap, with the fastest getting first place on the grid, referred to as <a href="/wiki/Pole_position" title="Pole position">pole position</a>. From 1996 to 2002, the format was a one-hour shootout. This approach lasted until the end of 2002 before the rules were changed again because the teams were not running in the early part of the session to take advantage of better track conditions later on.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>87<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Grids were generally limited to 26 cars – if the race had more entries, qualification would also decide which drivers would start the race. During the early 1990s, the number of entries was so high that the worst-performing teams had to enter a <a href="/wiki/Pre-qualification_(Formula_One)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pre-qualification (Formula One)">pre-qualifying</a> session, with the fastest cars allowed through to the main qualifying session. The qualifying format began to change in the early 2000s, with the FIA experimenting with limiting the number of laps, determining the aggregate time over two sessions, and allowing each driver only one qualifying lap.
</p><p>The current qualifying system was adopted in the 2006 season. Known as "knock-out" qualifying, it is split into three periods, known as Q1, Q2, and Q3. In each period, drivers run qualifying laps to attempt to advance to the next period, with the slowest drivers being "knocked out" of qualification (but not necessarily the race) at the end of the period and their grid positions set within the rearmost five based on their best lap times. Drivers are allowed as many laps as they wish within each period. After each period, all times are reset, and only a driver's <a href="/wiki/Fastest_lap" title="Fastest lap">fastest lap</a> in that period (barring infractions) counts. Any timed lap started before the end of that period may be completed and will count toward that driver's placement. The number of cars eliminated in each period is dependent on the total number of cars entered into the championship.<sup id="cite_ref-Qual_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Qual-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Currently, with 20 cars, Q1 runs for 18 minutes, and eliminates the slowest five drivers. During this period, any driver whose best lap takes longer than <a href="/wiki/107%25_rule" title="107% rule">107%</a> of the fastest time in Q1 will not be allowed to start the race without permission from the stewards. Otherwise, all drivers proceed to the race albeit in the worst starting positions. This rule does not affect drivers in Q2 or Q3. In Q2, the 15 remaining drivers have 15 minutes to set one of the ten fastest times and proceed to the next period. Finally, Q3 lasts 12 minutes and sees the remaining ten drivers decide the first ten grid positions. At the beginning of the 2016 Formula 1 season, the FIA introduced a new qualifying format, whereby drivers were knocked out every 90 seconds after a certain amount of time had passed in each session. The aim was to mix up grid positions for the race, but due to unpopularity, the FIA reverted to the above qualifying format for the Chinese GP, after running the format for only two races.<sup id="cite_ref-Qual_88-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Qual-88"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>88<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Each car is allocated one set of the softest tyres for use in Q3. The cars that qualify for Q3 must return them after Q3; the cars that do not qualify for Q3 can use them during the race.<sup id="cite_ref-2020Regs_89-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2020Regs-89"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>89<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2022, all drivers are given a free choice of tyre to use at the start of the Grand Prix,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>90<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> whereas in previous years only the drivers that did not participate in Q3 had free tyre choice for the start of the race. Any penalties that affect grid position are applied at the end of qualifying. Grid penalties can be applied for driving infractions in the previous or current Grand Prix, or for changing a gearbox or engine component. If a car fails scrutineering, the driver will be excluded from qualifying but will be allowed to start the race from the back of the grid at the race stewards' discretion.
</p><p>2021 saw the trialling of a 'sprint qualifying' race on the Saturday of three race weekends, with the intention of testing the new approach to qualifying. The traditional qualifying would determine the starting order for the sprint, and the result of the sprint would then determine the start order for the Grand Prix.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>91<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The system returned for the 2022 season, now titled the 'sprint'.<sup id="cite_ref-sprint_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-sprint-92"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>92<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> From 2023, sprint races no longer impacted the start order for the main race, which would be determined by traditional qualifying. Sprints would have their own qualifying session, titled the 'sprint shootout';<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>93<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> such a system made its debut at the <a href="/wiki/2023_Azerbaijan_Grand_Prix" title="2023 Azerbaijan Grand Prix">2023 Azerbaijan Grand Prix</a> and is set to be used throughout all sprint sessions in place of the traditional second free practice session. Sprint qualifying sessions are run much shorter than traditional qualifying, and each session required teams to fit new tyres – mediums for SQ1 and SQ2, and softs for SQ3 – otherwise they cannot participate in the session.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>94<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Race">Race</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=10" title="Edit section: Race"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The race begins with a warm-up lap, after which the cars assemble on the starting grid in the order they qualified. This lap is often referred to as the formation lap, as the cars lap in formation with no overtaking (although a driver who makes a mistake may regain lost ground). The warm-up lap allows drivers to check the condition of the track and their car, gives the tyres a chance to warm up to increase traction and grip, and also gives the pit crews time to clear themselves and their equipment from the grid for the race start.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Jacques_Villeneuve_(Sauber)_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Jacques_Villeneuve_%28Sauber%29_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg/220px-Jacques_Villeneuve_%28Sauber%29_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="76" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Jacques_Villeneuve_%28Sauber%29_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg/330px-Jacques_Villeneuve_%28Sauber%29_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/12/Jacques_Villeneuve_%28Sauber%29_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg/440px-Jacques_Villeneuve_%28Sauber%29_qualifying_at_US_Grand_Prix_2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1991" data-file-height="685"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Jacques_Villeneuve" title="Jacques Villeneuve">Jacques Villeneuve</a> qualifying at the <a href="/wiki/2005_United_States_Grand_Prix" title="2005 United States Grand Prix">2005 United States Grand Prix</a> in his <a href="/wiki/Sauber_C24" title="Sauber C24">Sauber C24</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Once all the cars have formed on the grid, after the medical car positions itself behind the pack,<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>95<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> a light system above the track indicates the start of the race: five red lights are illuminated at intervals of one second; they are all then extinguished simultaneously after an unspecified time (typically less than 3 seconds) to signal the start of the race. The start procedure may be abandoned if a driver stalls on the grid or on the track in an unsafe position, signalled by raising their arm. If this happens, the procedure restarts: a new formation lap begins with the offending car removed from the grid. The race may also be restarted in the event of a serious accident or dangerous conditions, with the original start voided. The race may be started from behind the Safety Car if race control feels a racing start would be excessively dangerous, such as extremely heavy rainfall. As of the <a href="/wiki/2019_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2019 Formula One World Championship">2019</a> season, there will always be a standing restart. If due to heavy rainfall a start behind the safety car is necessary, then after the track has dried sufficiently, drivers will form up for a standing start. There is no formation lap when races start behind the Safety Car.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>96<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Under normal circumstances, the winner of the race is the first driver to cross the finish line having completed a set number of laps. Race officials may end the race early (putting out a red flag) due to unsafe conditions such as extreme rainfall, and it must finish within two hours, although races are only likely to last this long in the case of extreme weather or if the safety car is deployed during the race. When a situation justifies pausing the race without terminating it, <a href="/wiki/List_of_red-flagged_Formula_One_races" title="List of red-flagged Formula One races">the red flag is deployed</a>; since 2005, a ten-minute warning is given before the race is resumed behind the safety car, which leads the field for a lap before it returns to the pit lane (before then the race resumed in race order from the penultimate lap before the red flag was shown).
</p><p>In the 1950s, race distances varied from 300 km (190 mi) to 600 km (370 mi). The maximum race length was reduced to 400 km (250 mi) in 1966 and 325 km (202 mi) in 1971. The race length was standardized to the current 305 km (190 mi) in 1989. However, street races like <a href="/wiki/Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="Monaco Grand Prix">Monaco</a> have shorter distances, to keep under the two-hour limit.
</p><p>Drivers may overtake one another for position over the course of the race. If a leader comes across a backmarker (slower car) who has completed fewer laps, the back marker is shown a blue flag<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>97<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> telling them that they are obliged to allow the leader to overtake them. The slower car is said to be "lapped" and, once the leader finishes the race, is classified as finishing the race "one lap down". A driver can be lapped numerous times, by any car in front of them. A driver who fails to complete more than 90% of the race distance is shown as "not classified" in the results.
</p><p>Throughout the race, drivers may make <a href="/wiki/Pit_stop" title="Pit stop">pit stops</a> to change tyres and repair damage (from 1994 to 2009 inclusive, they could also refuel). Different teams and drivers employ different pit stop strategies in order to maximise their car's potential. Three dry tyre compounds, with different durability and adhesion characteristics, are available to drivers. Over the course of a race, drivers must use two of the three available compounds. The different compounds have different levels of performance and choosing when to use which compound is a key tactical decision to make. Different tyres have <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_tyres#Tyre_summary" title="Formula One tyres">different colours on their sidewalls</a>; this allows spectators to understand the strategies.
</p><p>Under wet conditions, drivers may switch to one of two specialised wet weather tyres with additional grooves (one "intermediate", for mild wet conditions, such as after recent rain, one "full wet", for racing in or immediately after rain). A driver must make at least one stop to use two tyre compounds; up to three stops are typically made, although further stops may be necessary to fix damage or if weather conditions change. If rain tyres are used, drivers are no longer obliged to use two types of dry tyres.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Race_director">Race director</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=11" title="Edit section: Race director"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Race_director#Formula_One" title="Race director">Race director § Formula One</a></div>
<p>This role involves managing the logistics of each F1 Grand Prix, inspecting cars in <a href="/wiki/Parc_ferm%C3%A9" title="Parc fermé">parc fermé</a> before a race, enforcing FIA rules, and controlling the lights which start each race. As the head of the race officials, the race director also plays a large role in resolving disputes among teams and drivers. The race director may also refer incidents to the race stewards, who may give penalties, such as drive-through penalties (or stop-and-go penalties), demotions on a pre-race start grid, race disqualifications and fines should parties break regulations. As of the <a href="/wiki/2024_Las_Vegas_Grand_Prix" title="2024 Las Vegas Grand Prix">2024 Las Vegas Grand Prix</a>, the race director is <a href="/wiki/Rui_Marques_(Formula_One)" title="Rui Marques (Formula One)">Rui Marques</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Herbie_Blash" title="Herbie Blash">Herbie Blash</a> as a permanent advisor.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>98<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>99<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading4"><h4 id="Safety_car">Safety car</h4><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=12" title="Edit section: Safety car"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Safety_car#Formula_One" title="Safety car">Safety car § Formula One</a></div>
<p>In the event of an incident that risks the safety of competitors or trackside <a href="/wiki/Motorsport_marshal" title="Motorsport marshal">race marshals</a>, race officials may choose to deploy the <a href="/wiki/Safety_car" title="Safety car">safety car</a>. This in effect suspends the race, with drivers following the safety car around the track at its speed in race order, with no overtaking permitted. Cars that have been lapped may, during the safety car period and depending on circumstances permitted by the race director, be allowed to un-lap themselves in order to ensure a smoother restart and to avoid blue flags being immediately thrown upon the resumption of the race with many of the cars in very close proximity to each other. The safety car circulates until the danger is cleared; after it comes in, the race restarts with a <a href="/wiki/Rolling_start" title="Rolling start">rolling start</a>. Pit stops under a safety car are permitted, and in many cases can offer a great advantage to teams who are able to pit and change tyres prior to the end of the safety car period.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>100<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On the lap in which the safety car returns to the pit lane, the leading car takes over the role of the safety car until the timing line. After crossing this line, drivers are allowed to start racing for track position once more.
</p>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mercedes-Benz" title="Mercedes-Benz">Mercedes-Benz</a> has supplied a variety of its <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-AMG" title="Mercedes-AMG">Mercedes-AMG</a> models to Formula One to use as the safety car since 1996.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>101<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> From 2021 onwards, <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin" title="Aston Martin">Aston Martin</a> has supplied the <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin_Vantage_(2018)" title="Aston Martin Vantage (2018)">Vantage</a> share duties with Mercedes-AMGs.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>102<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></p><figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg/220px-Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg/330px-Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg/440px-Formula_1_Safety_Car_Mercedes-AMG_GT_R.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4878" data-file-height="3252"></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-AMG_GT" title="Mercedes-AMG GT">Mercedes-AMG GT R</a> safety car at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Hungarian_Grand_Prix" title="2019 Hungarian Grand Prix">2019 Hungarian Grand Prix</a></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img alt="An Aston Martin Safety Car during the 2022 Formula One World Championship" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg/220px-Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="137" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg/330px-Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e1/Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg/440px-Aston_Martin_Safety_Car_F1_2022.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4065" data-file-height="2533"></a><figcaption>An <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin_Vantage_(2018)#F1_Safety_Car" title="Aston Martin Vantage (2018)">Aston Martin Safety Car</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2022_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2022 Formula One World Championship">2022 Formula One World Championship</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Since 2000, the main safety car driver has been German ex-racing driver <a href="/wiki/Bernd_Mayl%C3%A4nder" title="Bernd Mayländer">Bernd Mayländer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>103<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> He is usually joined by FIA technical assistant Richard Darker, who relays information between the safety car and race control.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>104<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading5"><h5 id="Virtual_Safety_Car">Virtual Safety Car</h5><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=13" title="Edit section: Virtual Safety Car"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Safety_car#Virtual_safety_car_(VSC)" title="Safety car">Safety car § Virtual safety car (VSC)</a></div>
<p>Following an accident at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Japanese_Grand_Prix" title="2014 Japanese Grand Prix">2014 Japanese Grand Prix</a>, which saw driver <a href="/wiki/Jules_Bianchi" title="Jules Bianchi">Jules Bianchi</a> suffer a serious head injury that led to his death, the FIA established an "accident panel" to investigate the dynamics of the accident and ways to minimise the risk of a crash during similar circumstances that do not warrant the deployment of a safety car and cannot be simply managed with <a href="/wiki/Racing_flags#Yellow_flag" title="Racing flags">yellow flags</a>. When the virtual safety car is deployed, the virtual marshal panels around the track display "VSC". All drivers receive a "VSC" notice on their steering wheels, and they must all keep their lap times above a pre-determined minimum, also known as keeping a positive delta.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>105<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The system was first implemented during the <a href="/wiki/2015_Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="2015 Monaco Grand Prix">2015 Monaco Grand Prix</a>, before being upgraded to a full safety car, following a collision between <a href="/wiki/Max_Verstappen" title="Max Verstappen">Max Verstappen</a> and <a href="/wiki/Romain_Grosjean" title="Romain Grosjean">Romain Grosjean</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>106<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Flags">Flags</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=14" title="Edit section: Flags"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Racing_flags" title="Racing flags">Racing flags</a></div>
<p>Flags specifications and usage are prescribed by Appendix H of the <a href="/wiki/FIA" class="mw-redirect" title="FIA">FIA</a>'s International Sporting Code.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>107<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tbody><tr>
<th>Flag
</th>
<th>Name
</th>
<th>Meaning
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th rowspan="3"><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg/50px-Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg/75px-Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg/100px-Auto_Racing_Yellow.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a></span>
</th>
<th>SC Board
<p>(Safety Car)
</p>
</th>
<td>Shown in conjunction with a yellow flag to indicate that the <a href="/wiki/Safety_Car" class="mw-redirect" title="Safety Car">Safety Car</a> is on track. Full course yellow flag applies. Drivers must hold position and slow down.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>VSC Board
<p>(Virtual Safety Car)
</p>
</th>
<td>Shown in conjunction with a yellow flag to indicate that the <a href="/wiki/Safety_car#Virtual_safety_car_(VSC)" title="Safety car">virtual safety car</a> is in use. During this time, the drivers are given minimum sector times that they must stay above. Full course double yellow flag applies. The car's time relative to this set time is measured at each marshalling post (approximately every 50 m), and the difference is referred to as the car's "delta" time. This delta time is reported to the driver, and must remain positive throughout the VSC period else the driver will be penalised.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>108<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>Yellow
</th>
<td>Indicates a hazard on or near the track (waved yellows indicate a hazard <i>on the track</i>, frozen yellows indicate a hazard <i>near the track</i>). Double waved yellows inform drivers that they must slow down as marshals are working on or near to the track and drivers should be prepared to stop.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Auto_Racing_Green.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Auto_Racing_Green.svg/50px-Auto_Racing_Green.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Auto_Racing_Green.svg/75px-Auto_Racing_Green.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Auto_Racing_Green.svg/100px-Auto_Racing_Green.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Green
</th>
<td>Normal racing conditions apply. This is usually shown following a yellow flag to indicate that the hazard has been passed. A green flag is shown at all stations for the lap following the end of a full-course yellow (or safety car). A green flag is also shown at the start of a session.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Auto_Racing_Oil.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Auto_Racing_Oil.svg/50px-Auto_Racing_Oil.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Auto_Racing_Oil.svg/75px-Auto_Racing_Oil.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/56/Auto_Racing_Oil.svg/100px-Auto_Racing_Oil.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Yellow and red striped
</th>
<td>Slippery track, due to oil, water, or loose debris. Can be seen 'rocked' from side to side (not waved) to indicate a small animal on track.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg/50px-Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg/75px-Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg/100px-Auto_Racing_Plain_Blue.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Blue
</th>
<td>A blue flag indicates that the driver in front must let faster cars behind them pass because they are being lapped. If the flag is missed 3 times, the driver could be penalised. Accompanied by the driver's number.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_white_flag.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/F1_white_flag.svg/50px-F1_white_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/F1_white_flag.svg/75px-F1_white_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/F1_white_flag.svg/100px-F1_white_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="384"></a></span>
</th>
<th>White
</th>
<td>Indicates that there is a slow car ahead, either a race car or a course vehicle. Often waved at the end of the pit lane when a car is about to leave the pits.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg/50px-F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg/75px-F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/45/F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg/100px-F1_black_flag_with_orange_circle.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="384"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Black and orange circle
</th>
<td>Car is damaged or has a mechanical problem, must return to the pit lane immediately. Will be accompanied by driver's number
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg/50px-F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg/75px-F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg/100px-F1_black_and_white_diagonal_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="384"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Half black half white
</th>
<td>Warns a driver for poor sportsmanship or dangerous behaviour. Can be followed by a Black flag upon further infringement. Accompanied by the driver's number.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:Auto_Racing_Black.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Auto_Racing_Black.svg/50px-Auto_Racing_Black.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Auto_Racing_Black.svg/75px-Auto_Racing_Black.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Auto_Racing_Black.svg/100px-Auto_Racing_Black.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="384"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Black
</th>
<td>Driver is disqualified. Will be accompanied by the driver's number. This can be issued after a Half Black Half White flag.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_red_flag.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F1_red_flag.svg/50px-F1_red_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="38" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F1_red_flag.svg/75px-F1_red_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/F1_red_flag.svg/100px-F1_red_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="384"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Red
</th>
<td>A red flag immediately halts a race or session when conditions become too dangerous to continue.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th><span typeof="mw:File"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_chequered_flag.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/F1_chequered_flag.svg/50px-F1_chequered_flag.svg.png" decoding="async" width="50" height="39" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/F1_chequered_flag.svg/75px-F1_chequered_flag.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/F1_chequered_flag.svg/100px-F1_chequered_flag.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="398"></a></span>
</th>
<th>Chequered flag
</th>
<td>End of the practice, qualifying, or racing session.
</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>The format of the race has changed little through <a href="/wiki/History_of_Formula_One" title="History of Formula One">Formula One's history</a>. The main changes have revolved around what is allowed at pit stops. In the early days of Grand Prix racing, a driver would be allowed to continue a race in their teammate's car should theirs develop a problem – in the modern era, cars are so carefully fitted to drivers that this has become impossible. In recent years, the emphasis has been on changing refuelling and tyre change regulations.
</p><p>Since the 2010 season, refuelling – which was reintroduced in 1994 – has not been allowed, to encourage less tactical racing following safety concerns. The rule requiring both compounds of tyre to be used during the race was introduced in 2007, again to encourage racing on the track. The safety car is another relatively recent innovation that reduced the need to deploy the red flag, allowing races to be completed on time for a growing international live television audience.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Points_system">Points system</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=15" title="Edit section: Points system"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
