<figure typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg/217px-Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg" decoding="async" width="217" height="325" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg/325px-Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg/433px-Drivers%27_World_Championship_trophy_2004_replica_front1_2019_Michael_Schumacher_Private_Collection.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1707" data-file-height="2560"></a><figcaption>The Formula One trophy given to the drivers' champion at the end of the year</figcaption></figure>
<p>Various systems for awarding championship points have been used since 1950. The current system, in place since 2010,<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>a<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> awards the top ten cars points in the Drivers' and Constructors' Championships, with the winner receiving 25 points. All points won at each race are added up, and the driver and constructor with the most points at the end of the season are crowned World Champions. Regardless of whether a driver stays with the same team throughout the season, or switches teams, all points earned by them count for the Drivers' Championship.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>109<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A driver must be classified in order to receive points, as of 2022<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, a driver must complete at least 90% of the race distance in order to receive points. Therefore, it is possible for a driver to receive points even if they retired before the end of the race.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>110<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>From some time between the <a href="/wiki/1977_Formula_One_season" title="1977 Formula One season">1977</a> and <a href="/wiki/1980_Formula_One_season" title="1980 Formula One season">1980 seasons</a> to the end of the <a href="/wiki/2021_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2021 Formula One World Championship">2021 season</a> if less than 75% of the race laps were completed by the winner, then only half of the points listed in the table were awarded to the drivers and constructors. This has happened on only five occasions in the history of the championship, and it had a notable influence on the final standing of the <a href="/wiki/1984_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1984 Formula One World Championship">1984</a> season. The last occurrence was at the <a href="/wiki/2021_Belgian_Grand_Prix" title="2021 Belgian Grand Prix">2021 Belgian Grand Prix</a> when the race was called off after just three laps behind a safety car due to torrential rain.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>111<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>112<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The half points rule was replaced by a distance-dependent gradual scale system for <a href="/wiki/2022_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2022 Formula One World Championship">2022</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-:3_114-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:3-114"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>113<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Constructors">Constructors</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=16" title="Edit section: Constructors"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_constructors" title="List of Formula One constructors">List of Formula One constructors</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_engine_constructors" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Formula One engine constructors">List of Formula One engine constructors</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Constructors%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Constructors' Champions">List of Formula One World Constructors' Champions</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg/220px-FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg/330px-FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg/440px-FIA_F1_Austria_2022_Nr._16_Leclerc.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3954" data-file-height="2224"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari</a> (pictured with <a href="/wiki/Charles_Leclerc" title="Charles Leclerc">Charles Leclerc</a>) have competed in every season.</figcaption></figure>
<p>A Formula One constructor is the entity credited for designing the chassis and the engine.<sup id="cite_ref-:0_115-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:0-115"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>114<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> If both are designed by the same company, that company receives sole credit as the constructor (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari</a>). If they are designed by different companies, both are credited, and the name of the chassis designer is placed before that of the engine designer (e.g., <span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/McLaren" title="McLaren">McLaren</a>-<a href="/wiki/Mercedes_AMG_High_Performance_Powertrains" title="Mercedes AMG High Performance Powertrains">Mercedes</a></span>). All constructors are scored individually, even if they share either chassis or engine with another constructor (e.g., <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">Williams</a>-<a href="/wiki/Ford_Motor_Company" title="Ford Motor Company">Ford</a>, <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">Williams</a>-<a href="/wiki/Honda_in_Formula_One" title="Honda in Formula One">Honda</a> in <a href="/wiki/1983_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1983 Formula One World Championship">1983</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>115<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Since <a href="/wiki/1981_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1981 Formula One World Championship">1981</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>116<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Formula One teams have been required to build the chassis in which they compete, and consequently the distinction between the terms "team" and "constructor" became less pronounced, though engines may still be produced by a different entity. This requirement distinguishes the sport from series such as the <a href="/wiki/IndyCar_Series" title="IndyCar Series">IndyCar Series</a> which allows teams to purchase chassis, and "<a href="/wiki/Spec_racing" class="mw-redirect" title="Spec racing">spec series</a>" such as <a href="/wiki/FIA_Formula_2_Championship" title="FIA Formula 2 Championship">Formula 2</a> which require all cars be kept to an identical specification. It also effectively prohibits <a href="/wiki/Privateer_(motorsport)" title="Privateer (motorsport)">privateers</a>, which were common even in Formula One well into the 1970s.
</p><p>The sport's debut season, <a href="/wiki/1950_Formula_One_season" title="1950 Formula One season">1950</a>, saw eighteen teams compete, but due to high costs, many dropped out quickly. In fact, such was the scarcity of competitive cars for much of the first decade of Formula One that Formula Two cars were admitted to fill the grids. Ferrari is the oldest Formula One team, the only still-active team which competed in 1950.
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg/220px-Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg/330px-Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg/440px-Ayrton_Senna_1988_Canada.jpg 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="480"></a><figcaption>McLaren won all but one race in <a href="/wiki/1988_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1988 Formula One World Championship">1988</a> with engine partner <a href="/wiki/Honda_in_Formula_One" title="Honda in Formula One">Honda</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_(1).jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_%281%29.jpg/220px-Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="142" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_%281%29.jpg/330px-Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_%281%29.jpg/440px-Niko_Hulkenberg-Test_Days_2018_Circuit_Barcelona_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4114" data-file-height="2656"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Renault_in_Formula_One" title="Renault in Formula One">Renault</a> (pictured here with <a href="/wiki/Nico_H%C3%BClkenberg" title="Nico Hülkenberg">Nico Hülkenberg</a>) has had an active role in Formula One as both constructor and engine supplier since <a href="/wiki/1977_Formula_One_season" title="1977 Formula One season">1977</a>.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Early manufacturer involvement came in the form of a "factory team" or "<a href="/wiki/Works_team#Works_or_factory_teams_in_motorsport" title="Works team">works team</a>" (that is, one owned and staffed by a major car company), such as those of Alfa Romeo, Ferrari, or Renault. Ferrari holds the record for having won the most Constructors' Championships (sixteen).
</p><p>Companies such as <a href="/wiki/Coventry_Climax" title="Coventry Climax">Climax</a>, <a href="/wiki/Repco" title="Repco">Repco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cosworth" title="Cosworth">Cosworth</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hart_Racing_Engines" title="Hart Racing Engines">Hart</a>, <a href="/wiki/Judd_(engine)" title="Judd (engine)">Judd</a> and <a href="/wiki/Supertec" title="Supertec">Supertec</a>, which had no direct team affiliation, often sold engines to teams that could not afford to manufacture them. In the early years, independently owned Formula One teams sometimes also built their engines, though this became less common with the increased involvement of major car manufacturers such as BMW, Ferrari, Honda, Mercedes-Benz, Renault, and Toyota, whose large budgets rendered privately built engines less competitive. Cosworth was the last independent engine supplier.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>117<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> It is estimated the major teams spend between €100 and €200 million ($125–$225 million) per year per manufacturer on engines alone.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>118<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the 2007 season, for the first time since the 1981 rule, two teams used chassis built by other teams. <a href="/wiki/Super_Aguri" class="mw-redirect" title="Super Aguri">Super Aguri</a> started the season using a modified <a href="/wiki/Honda_RA106" title="Honda RA106">Honda Racing RA106</a> chassis (used by Honda the previous year), while <a href="/wiki/Toro_Rosso" class="mw-redirect" title="Toro Rosso">Scuderia Toro Rosso</a> used the same chassis used by the parent <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing" title="Red Bull Racing">Red Bull Racing</a> team, which was formally designed by a separate subsidiary. The usage of these loopholes was ended for 2010 with the publication of new technical regulations, which require each constructor to own the intellectual property rights to their chassis,<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>119<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>120<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The regulations continue to allow a team to subcontract the design and construction of the chassis to a third-party, an option used by the <a href="/wiki/HRT_Formula_1_Team" title="HRT Formula 1 Team">HRT team</a> in 2010 and <a href="/wiki/Haas_F1_Team" title="Haas F1 Team">Haas</a> currently.
</p><p>Although teams rarely disclose information about their budgets, it is estimated they range from US$66 million to US$400 million each.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>121<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Entering a new team in the Formula One World Championship requires a $200 million up-front payment to the FIA, which is then shared equally among the existing teams.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>122<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As a consequence, constructors desiring to enter Formula One often prefer to buy an existing team: <a href="/wiki/British_American_Racing" title="British American Racing">BAR</a>'s purchase of <a href="/wiki/Tyrrell_Racing" title="Tyrrell Racing">Tyrrell</a> and <a href="/wiki/Midland_F1_Racing" title="Midland F1 Racing">Midland</a>'s purchase of Jordan allowed both of these teams to sidestep the large deposit and secure the benefits the team already had, such as TV revenue.
</p><p>Seven out of the ten teams competing in Formula One are based close to London in an area centred around Oxford. Ferrari have both their chassis and engine assembly in Maranello, Italy. The <a href="/wiki/RB_Formula_One_Team" class="mw-redirect" title="RB Formula One Team">RB Formula One Team</a> is based close to Ferrari in Faenza, whilst Sauber Motorsport is based near Zurich in Switzerland.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>123<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>124<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Drivers">Drivers</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=17" title="Edit section: Drivers"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_drivers" title="List of Formula One drivers">List of Formula One drivers</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_World_Drivers%27_Champions" title="List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions">List of Formula One World Drivers' Champions</a>, and <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_driver_numbers" title="List of Formula One driver numbers">List of Formula One driver numbers</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Lap4_Canada2005.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Lap4_Canada2005.jpg/220px-Lap4_Canada2005.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="150" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Lap4_Canada2005.jpg/330px-Lap4_Canada2005.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Lap4_Canada2005.jpg/440px-Lap4_Canada2005.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1393"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/2005_Canadian_Grand_Prix" title="2005 Canadian Grand Prix">2005 Canadian Grand Prix</a>: <a href="/wiki/Kimi_R%C3%A4ikk%C3%B6nen" title="Kimi Räikkönen">Kimi Räikkönen</a> leading Michael Schumacher, with <a href="/wiki/Jarno_Trulli" title="Jarno Trulli">Jarno Trulli</a> (<a href="/wiki/Toyota_Racing_(Formula_One_team)" class="mw-redirect" title="Toyota Racing (Formula One team)">Toyota</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Takuma_Sato" title="Takuma Sato">Takuma Sato</a> (<a href="/wiki/British_American_Racing" title="British American Racing">BAR</a>-<a href="/wiki/Honda_in_Formula_One" title="Honda in Formula One">Honda</a>) fighting for position</figcaption></figure>
<p>Every team in Formula One must run two cars in every session in a Grand Prix weekend, and every team may use up to four drivers in a season.<sup id="cite_ref-DriveChang_85-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DriveChang-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A team may also run two additional drivers in Free Practice sessions,<sup id="cite_ref-DriveChang_85-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DriveChang-85"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>85<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which are often used to test potential new drivers for a career as a Formula One driver or gain experienced drivers to evaluate the car.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>125<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>126<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Most drivers are contracted for at least the duration of a season, with driver changes taking place in-between seasons, in comparison to early years when drivers often competed on an ad hoc basis from race to race. Each competitor must be in the possession of a <a href="/wiki/FIA_Super_Licence" title="FIA Super Licence">FIA Super Licence</a> to compete in a Grand Prix,<sup id="cite_ref-AppL_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AppL-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which is issued to drivers who have met the criteria of success in junior motorsport categories and having achieved 300 kilometres (190 mi) of running in a Formula One car. Drivers may also be issued a Super Licence by the <a href="/wiki/World_Motor_Sport_Council" class="mw-redirect" title="World Motor Sport Council">World Motor Sport Council</a> if they fail to meet the criteria.<sup id="cite_ref-AppL_128-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AppL-128"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>127<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Although most drivers earn their seat on ability, commercial considerations also come into play with teams having to satisfy sponsors and financial demands.
</p><p>Teams also contract test and reserve drivers to stand in for regular drivers when necessary and develop the team's car; although with the reduction on testing the reserve drivers' role mainly takes places on a <a href="/wiki/Simulator" class="mw-redirect" title="Simulator">simulator</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>128<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> such as <a href="/wiki/RFactor_Pro" class="mw-redirect" title="RFactor Pro">rFactor Pro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-rFPro_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rFPro-130"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>129<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>130<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which is used by most of the F1 teams.<sup id="cite_ref-rfProMars_132-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rfProMars-132"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>131<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-rFProISI_133-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-rFProISI-133"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>132<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Each driver chooses an unassigned number from 2 to 99 (excluding 17 which was retired following the death of <a href="/wiki/Jules_Bianchi" title="Jules Bianchi">Jules Bianchi</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>133<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> upon entering Formula One and keeps that number during their time in the series. The number one is reserved for the reigning Drivers' Champion, who retains their previous number and may choose to use it instead of the number one.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>134<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> At the onset of the championship, numbers were allocated by race organisers on an ad hoc basis from race to race.<sup id="cite_ref-F1_number_136-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F1_number-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Permanent numbers were introduced in <a href="/wiki/1973_Formula_One_season" title="1973 Formula One season">1973</a> to take effect in <a href="/wiki/1974_Formula_One_season" title="1974 Formula One season">1974</a>, when teams were allocated numbers in ascending order based on the Constructors' Championship standings at the end of the 1973 season. The teams would hold those numbers from season to season with the exception of the team with the World Drivers' Champion, which would swap its numbers with the one and two of the previous champion's team. New entrants were allocated spare numbers, with the exception of the number 13 which had been unused since <a href="/wiki/1976_Formula_One_season" title="1976 Formula One season">1976</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>136<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As teams kept their numbers for long periods of time, car numbers became associated with a team, such as <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari's</a> 27 and 28.<sup id="cite_ref-F1_number_136-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-F1_number-136"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>135<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A different system was used from <a href="/wiki/1996_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1996 Formula One World Championship">1996</a> to <a href="/wiki/2013_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2013 Formula One World Championship">2013</a>: at the start of each season, the current Drivers' Champion was designated number one, their teammate number two, and the rest of the teams assigned ascending numbers according to previous season's Constructors' Championship order.<sup id="cite_ref-DrivNo_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DrivNo-138"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>137<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2024<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, a total of 34 separate drivers have won the World Drivers' Championship, with Michael Schumacher and Lewis Hamilton holding the record for most championships with seven. Lewis Hamilton achieved the most race wins, too, in 2020. <a href="/wiki/Jochen_Rindt" title="Jochen Rindt">Jochen Rindt</a> is the only posthumous World Champion, after his points total was not surpassed despite his fatal accident at the <a href="/wiki/1970_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="1970 Italian Grand Prix">1970 Italian Grand Prix</a>, with 4 races still remaining in the season. <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_drivers_from_the_United_Kingdom" title="Formula One drivers from the United Kingdom">Drivers from the United Kingdom</a> have been the most successful in the sport, with 20 championships among 10 drivers, and 316 wins.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>138<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Physical_demands">Physical demands</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=18" title="Edit section: Physical demands"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Driving in Formula One is highly demanding physically, with drivers typically burning around 1,000 calories per hour and losing 2–4 kg (4–9 lb) of weight per race.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>140<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A key reason for the physical demands is the extreme <a href="/wiki/G-force" title="G-force">g-forces</a> generated by driving at high speeds, with modern Formula One cars capable of generating forces of up to 6.5 <i>g</i>s when cornering, 6 <i>g</i>s when braking and 2 <i>g</i>s when accelerating.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>141<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>142<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>143<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> When a driver experiences 6 <i>g</i>, they will feel a force equivalent to six times their body weight; for a person weighing 80 kg (176 lb), this would be 480 kg (1,058 lb).<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>144<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Another factor is the high temperature inside the car, as the engine is mounted directly behind the driver. The temperature in the cockpit of a Formula One car can be as high as 60 °C (140 °F) and drivers have to wear several layers of fireproof <a href="/wiki/Racing_suit" title="Racing suit">racing clothing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>145<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>146<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The steering wheel and brake pedal also require considerable strength to operate. Before the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Power_steering" title="Power steering">power steering</a> in the 2000s, drivers had to cope with steering forces of up to 40–50 newton-metres (30–37 lb⋅ft),<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>147<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>148<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> while achieving maximum braking power requires drivers to apply around 150 kg (330 lb) of force to the brake pedal.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>149<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Drivers also need to be light, as every extra kilogram of weight noticeably reduces performance.<sup id="cite_ref-:2_140-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:2-140"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>139<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Drivers also need to train on cardiovascular fitness since heart rates can average more than 170 bpm during a race, this is more than a healthy adult would typically experience while running.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>150<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Feeder_series">Feeder series</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=19" title="Edit section: Feeder series"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg/220px-FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg/330px-FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg/440px-FIA_F2_Austria_2024_Nr._12_Colapinto.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4222" data-file-height="2374"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/FIA_Formula_2_Championship" title="FIA Formula 2 Championship">FIA Formula 2 Championship</a>, the main F1 feeder series since <a href="/wiki/2017_FIA_Formula_Two_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="2017 FIA Formula Two Championship">2017</a></figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg/220px-FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="124" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg/330px-FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg/440px-FIA_F3_Austria_2024_Nr._4_Fornaroli.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4110" data-file-height="2312"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/FIA_Formula_3_Championship" title="FIA Formula 3 Championship">FIA Formula 3 Championship</a>, the main F1 and F2 feeder series since <a href="/wiki/2019_FIA_Formula_3_Championship" title="2019 FIA Formula 3 Championship">2019</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Most F1 drivers start in <a href="/wiki/Kart_racing" title="Kart racing">kart racing</a> competitions and then come up through traditional European single-seater series like <a href="/wiki/Formula_Ford" title="Formula Ford">Formula Ford</a> and <a href="/wiki/Formula_Renault" title="Formula Renault">Formula Renault</a> to <a href="/wiki/Formula_3" class="mw-redirect" title="Formula 3">Formula 3</a>, and finally the <a href="/wiki/GP2_Series" title="GP2 Series">GP2 Series</a>. GP2 started in 2005, replacing <a href="/wiki/Formula_3000" title="Formula 3000">Formula 3000</a>, which itself had replaced <a href="/wiki/Formula_Two" title="Formula Two">Formula Two</a> as the last major stepping-stone into F1. GP2 was rebranded as the <a href="/wiki/FIA_Formula_2_Championship" title="FIA Formula 2 Championship">FIA Formula 2 Championship</a> in 2017. Most champions from this level graduate into F1, but 2006 GP2 champion Lewis Hamilton became the first F2, F3000 or GP2 champion to win the Formula One drivers' title in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>151<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Drivers are not required to have competed at this level before entering Formula One. <a href="/wiki/British_F3" class="mw-redirect" title="British F3">British F3</a> has supplied many F1 drivers, with champions, including <a href="/wiki/Nigel_Mansell" title="Nigel Mansell">Nigel Mansell</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ayrton_Senna" title="Ayrton Senna">Ayrton Senna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mika_H%C3%A4kkinen" title="Mika Häkkinen">Mika Häkkinen</a> having moved straight from that series to Formula One, and <a href="/wiki/Max_Verstappen" title="Max Verstappen">Max Verstappen</a> made his F1 debut following a single season in <a href="/wiki/FIA_Formula_3_European_Championship" title="FIA Formula 3 European Championship">European F3</a>. More rarely a driver may be picked from an even lower level, as was the case with <a href="/wiki/2007_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2007 Formula One World Championship">2007</a> World Champion <a href="/wiki/Kimi_R%C3%A4ikk%C3%B6nen" title="Kimi Räikkönen">Kimi Räikkönen</a>, who went straight from Formula Renault to F1.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>152<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/American_open-wheel_car_racing" title="American open-wheel car racing">American open-wheel car racing</a> has also contributed to the Formula One grid. <a href="/wiki/Champ_Car" class="mw-redirect" title="Champ Car">CART</a> champions <a href="/wiki/Mario_Andretti" title="Mario Andretti">Mario Andretti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Villeneuve" title="Jacques Villeneuve">Jacques Villeneuve</a> became F1 World Champions, while <a href="/wiki/Juan_Pablo_Montoya" title="Juan Pablo Montoya">Juan Pablo Montoya</a> won seven races in F1. Other CART (also known as ChampCar) champions, like <a href="/wiki/Michael_Andretti" title="Michael Andretti">Michael Andretti</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alessandro_Zanardi" class="mw-redirect" title="Alessandro Zanardi">Alessandro Zanardi</a> won no races in F1. Other drivers have taken different paths to F1; Damon Hill raced motorbikes, and Michael Schumacher raced in <a href="/wiki/Sports_car_racing" title="Sports car racing">sports cars</a>, albeit after climbing through the junior single-seater ranks. Former F1 driver <a href="/wiki/Paul_di_Resta" title="Paul di Resta">Paul di Resta</a> raced in <a href="/wiki/Deutsche_Tourenwagen_Masters" title="Deutsche Tourenwagen Masters">DTM</a> until he was signed with <a href="/wiki/Force_India" title="Force India">Force India</a> in 2011.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Grands_Prix">Grands Prix</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=20" title="Edit section: Grands Prix"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_Grands_Prix" title="List of Formula One Grands Prix">List of Formula One Grands Prix</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg/300px-Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg.png" decoding="async" width="300" height="152" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg/450px-Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/00/Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg/600px-Formula_1_all_over_the_world-2025.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="2754" data-file-height="1398"></a><figcaption>World map showing the location of Formula 1 Grands Prix: countries marked in green are on the current race schedule, those in dark grey have hosted a Formula One race in the past. (<i>De facto</i> status of the territories is shown.)</figcaption></figure>
<p>The number of Grands Prix held in a season has varied over the years. The inaugural <a href="/wiki/1950_Formula_One_season" title="1950 Formula One season">1950</a> World Championship season comprised only seven races, while the <a href="/wiki/2024_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2024 Formula One World Championship">2024</a> season contained 24 races, the highest number of World Championship races in one season.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>153<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> There were no more than 11 Grands Prix per season during the early decades of the championship, although a large number of non-championship Formula One events also took place. The number of Grands Prix increased to an average of 16 to 17 by the late 1970s, while non-championship events ended in 1983. More Grands Prix began to be held in the 2000s, and recent seasons have seen an average of 21 races. 
</p><p>Six of the original seven races took place in Europe; the only non-European race that counted towards the World Championship in 1950 was the <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">Indianapolis 500</a>, which was held to different regulations and later replaced by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Grand_Prix" title="United States Grand Prix">United States Grand Prix</a>. The F1 championship gradually expanded to other non-European countries. Argentina hosted the first South American Grand Prix in <a href="/wiki/1953_Formula_One_season" title="1953 Formula One season">1953</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Moroccan_Grand_Prix" title="Moroccan Grand Prix">Morocco</a> hosted the first African World Championship race in <a href="/wiki/1958_Formula_One_season" title="1958 Formula One season">1958</a>. Asia and Oceania followed (Japan in <a href="/wiki/1976_Formula_One_season" title="1976 Formula One season">1976</a> and Australia in <a href="/wiki/1985_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1985 Formula One World Championship">1985</a>), and the first race in the Middle East was held in <a href="/wiki/2004_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2004 Formula One World Championship">2004</a>. The 19 races of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2014 Formula One World Championship">2014</a> season were spread over every populated continent except for Africa, with 10 Grands Prix held outside Europe.
</p><p>Some of the Grands Prix pre-date the formation of the World Championship, such as the <a href="/wiki/French_Grand_Prix" title="French Grand Prix">French Grand Prix</a> and were incorporated into the championship as Formula One races in 1950. The <a href="/wiki/British_Grand_Prix" title="British Grand Prix">British</a> and <a href="/wiki/Italian_Grand_Prix" title="Italian Grand Prix">Italian</a> Grands Prix are the only events to have been held every Formula One season; other long-running races include the Belgian, German, and French Grands Prix. The <a href="/wiki/Monaco_Grand_Prix" title="Monaco Grand Prix">Monaco Grand Prix</a> was first held in 1929 and has run continuously since 1955 (with the exception of 2020) and is widely considered to be one of the most important and prestigious automobile races in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>154<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>All Grands Prix have traditionally been run during the day, until the inaugural <a href="/wiki/2008_Singapore_Grand_Prix" title="2008 Singapore Grand Prix">Singapore Grand Prix</a> hosted the first Formula One night race in 2008,<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>155<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> which was followed by the day–night <a href="/wiki/Abu_Dhabi_Grand_Prix" title="Abu Dhabi Grand Prix">Abu Dhabi Grand Prix</a> in 2009 and the <a href="/wiki/Bahrain_Grand_Prix" title="Bahrain Grand Prix">Bahrain Grand Prix</a> which converted to a night race in 2014. Other Grands Prix in Asia have had their start times adjusted to benefit the European television audience.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>156<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Contracted_Grands_Prix">Contracted Grands Prix</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=21" title="Edit section: Contracted Grands Prix"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>The following twenty-four Grands Prix, all of which appeared on the <a href="/wiki/2024_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2024 Formula One World Championship">2024</a> schedule, have a contract to be hosted at the listed circuits for the 2025 season: 
</p>
<table class="sortable wikitable jquery-tablesorter" style="font-size: 85%;">
<thead><tr>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Returning_additions_(2008–present)"><span id="Returning_additions_.282008.E2.80.93present.29"></span>Returning additions (2008–present)</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=22" title="Edit section: Returning additions (2008–present)"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><b>Bold</b> denotes the Grands Prix scheduled as part of the <a href="/wiki/2024_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2024 Formula One World Championship">2024</a> season.
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/European_Grand_Prix" title="European Grand Prix">European Grand Prix</a> at <a href="/wiki/Valencia_Street_Circuit" title="Valencia Street Circuit">Valencia Street Circuit</a> (2008–2012)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/United_States_Grand_Prix" title="United States Grand Prix">United States Grand Prix</a></b> at <a href="/wiki/Circuit_of_the_Americas" title="Circuit of the Americas">Circuit of the Americas</a> (2012–2019, 2021–present)</li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Austrian_Grand_Prix" title="Austrian Grand Prix">Austrian Grand Prix</a></b> at <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Ring" title="Red Bull Ring">Red Bull Ring</a> (2014–present)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Mexican_Grand_Prix" title="Mexican Grand Prix">Mexican Grand Prix</a> at <a href="/wiki/Aut%C3%B3dromo_Hermanos_Rodr%C3%ADguez" title="Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez">Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez</a> (2015–2019); renamed <b><a href="/wiki/Mexican_Grand_Prix" title="Mexican Grand Prix">Mexico City Grand Prix</a></b> (2021–present)<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>181<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/European_Grand_Prix" title="European Grand Prix">European Grand Prix</a> at <a href="/wiki/Baku_City_Circuit" title="Baku City Circuit">Baku City Circuit</a> (2016; renamed the <b><a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan_Grand_Prix" title="Azerbaijan Grand Prix">Azerbaijan Grand Prix</a></b> for 2017–2019, 2021–present)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/French_Grand_Prix" title="French Grand Prix">French Grand Prix</a> at <a href="/wiki/Circuit_Paul_Ricard" title="Circuit Paul Ricard">Circuit Paul Ricard</a> (2018–2019, 2021–2022)</li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Grand_Prix" title="Portuguese Grand Prix">Portuguese Grand Prix</a> at <a href="/wiki/Algarve_International_Circuit" title="Algarve International Circuit">Algarve International Circuit</a> (2020–2021)<sup id="cite_ref-POR-COVID_183-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-POR-COVID-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>b<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Imola_Circuit" title="Imola Circuit">Imola Circuit</a> with the <b><a href="/wiki/Emilia_Romagna_Grand_Prix" title="Emilia Romagna Grand Prix">Emilia Romagna Grand Prix</a></b> (2020–2022, 2024–present; previously hosted the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Grand_Prix" title="Italian Grand Prix">Italian Grand Prix</a> and the <a href="/wiki/San_Marino_Grand_Prix" title="San Marino Grand Prix">San Marino Grand Prix</a>)<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>c<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li><b><a href="/wiki/Dutch_Grand_Prix" title="Dutch Grand Prix">Dutch Grand Prix</a></b> at <a href="/wiki/Circuit_Zandvoort" title="Circuit Zandvoort">Circuit Zandvoort</a> (2021–present)</li></ul>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="New_Locations_Initiative_(2008–present)"><span id="New_Locations_Initiative_.282008.E2.80.93present.29"></span>New Locations Initiative (2008–present)</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=23" title="Edit section: New Locations Initiative (2008–present)"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><b>Bold</b> denotes the Grands Prix scheduled as part of the <a href="/wiki/2024_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2024 Formula One World Championship">2024</a> season.
</p><p>Since 2008, the Formula One Group has been targeting new "destination cities" to expand its global reach, with the aim to produce races from countries that have not previously been involved in the sport. This initiative started with the <a href="/wiki/2008_Singapore_Grand_Prix" title="2008 Singapore Grand Prix">2008 Singapore Grand Prix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>182<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Circuits">Circuits</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=24" title="Edit section: Circuits"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_circuits" title="List of Formula One circuits">List of Formula One circuits</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Monza_aerial_photo.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Monza_aerial_photo.jpg/220px-Monza_aerial_photo.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Monza_aerial_photo.jpg/330px-Monza_aerial_photo.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Monza_aerial_photo.jpg/440px-Monza_aerial_photo.jpg 2x" data-file-width="572" data-file-height="379"></a><figcaption>The <a href="/wiki/Autodromo_Nazionale_Monza" class="mw-redirect" title="Autodromo Nazionale Monza">Autodromo Nazionale Monza</a>, home to the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Grand_Prix" title="Italian Grand Prix">Italian Grand Prix</a>, is the oldest purpose-built track still in use today.</figcaption></figure>
<figure class="mw-default-size mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Circuit_Sochi.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Circuit_Sochi.svg/220px-Circuit_Sochi.svg.png" decoding="async" width="220" height="155" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Circuit_Sochi.svg/330px-Circuit_Sochi.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Circuit_Sochi.svg/440px-Circuit_Sochi.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="512" data-file-height="361"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Sochi_Autodrom" title="Sochi Autodrom">Sochi Autodrom</a>, host venue for the <a href="/wiki/Russian_Grand_Prix" title="Russian Grand Prix">Russian Grand Prix</a> from 2014 to 2021</figcaption></figure>
<p>Formula One races must be held on <a href="/wiki/List_of_motor_racing_circuits_by_FIA_grade#Grade_One" title="List of motor racing circuits by FIA grade">Grade One tracks</a>, the highest grade-rating issued by the FIA for tracks.<sup id="cite_ref-FIA_Super_187-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FIA_Super-187"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>184<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The layout and lap distance of each circuit can vary significantly as long as they stay within the FIA's regulations. In most cases, the tracks run in a <a href="/wiki/Clockwise" title="Clockwise">clockwise</a> direction, although there are a handful of tracks in the Championship that run anticlockwise.
</p><p>A typical circuit features a stretch of straight road on which the starting grid is situated, with the <a href="/wiki/Pit_stop" title="Pit stop">pit lane</a> normally located right next to it. The pit lane is home to each team's garage, where cars are stored and serviced before a race. During a <a href="/wiki/Pit_stop#Formula_One" title="Pit stop">pit stop</a>, drivers enter the pit lane to change their tyres, receive repairs or aerodynamic adjustments from their <a href="/wiki/Pit_crew" class="mw-redirect" title="Pit crew">pit crew</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Did_not_finish" title="Did not finish">retire</a> from the race (if the car is in a condition to do so). Prior to the <a href="/wiki/2010_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2010 Formula One World Championship">2010</a> season, pit stops also facilitated mid-race refueling of the cars.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>185<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Special pit roads and track markings help to make sure drivers pit and rejoin the track safely.
</p><p>Most of the circuits currently in use are specially constructed for competition, but the calendar also features several circuits that use converted public streets to varying degrees. These tracks include <a href="/wiki/Circuit_de_Monaco" title="Circuit de Monaco">Monaco</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albert_Park_Circuit" title="Albert Park Circuit">Melbourne</a>, <a href="/wiki/Marina_Bay_Street_Circuit" title="Marina Bay Street Circuit">Singapore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baku_City_Circuit" title="Baku City Circuit">Baku</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miami_International_Autodrome" title="Miami International Autodrome">Miami</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jeddah_Corniche_Circuit" title="Jeddah Corniche Circuit">Jeddah</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Strip_Circuit" title="Las Vegas Strip Circuit">Las Vegas</a>. Three-time World champion <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Piquet" title="Nelson Piquet">Nelson Piquet</a> famously described racing in Monaco as "like riding a bicycle around your living room".<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>186<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The Monaco Grand Prix holds a unique exception to the FIA's minimum race distance requirement—the Grand Prix only needs to last enough laps to cover a distance of 260 km, versus the standard 305 km.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>187<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>188<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Circuit design to protect the safety of drivers is becoming increasingly sophisticated, as exemplified by the <a href="/wiki/Bahrain_International_Circuit" title="Bahrain International Circuit">Bahrain International Circuit</a>, added in <a href="/wiki/2004_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2004 Formula One World Championship">2004</a> and designed – like most of F1's new circuits – by <a href="/wiki/Hermann_Tilke" title="Hermann Tilke">Hermann Tilke</a>. Several of the new circuits in F1, especially those designed by Tilke, have been criticised as lacking the "flow" of such classics as <a href="/wiki/Circuit_de_Spa-Francorchamps" title="Circuit de Spa-Francorchamps">Spa-Francorchamps</a> and Imola.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>189<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> His redesign of the Hockenheim circuit in Germany for example, while providing more capacity for grandstands and eliminating extremely long and dangerous straights, has been frowned upon by many who argue that part of the character of the Hockenheim circuits was the long and blinding straights into dark forest sections. These newer circuits, however, are generally agreed to meet the safety standards of modern Formula One better than the older ones.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>190<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Circuit_of_the_Americas" title="Circuit of the Americas">Circuit of the Americas</a> in <a href="/wiki/Austin,_Texas" title="Austin, Texas">Austin</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sochi_Autodrom" title="Sochi Autodrom">Sochi Autodrom</a> in <a href="/wiki/Sochi" title="Sochi">Sochi</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Baku_City_Circuit" title="Baku City Circuit">Baku City Circuit</a> in <a href="/wiki/Azerbaijan" title="Azerbaijan">Azerbaijan</a> have all been introduced as brand new tracks since 2012. In 2020, <a href="/wiki/Algarve_International_Circuit" title="Algarve International Circuit">Algarve International Circuit</a> debuted on the F1 calendar as the venue of the <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_Grand_Prix" title="Portuguese Grand Prix">Portuguese Grand Prix</a>, with the country having last hosted a race in 1996.<sup id="cite_ref-POR-COVID_183-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-POR-COVID-183"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>b<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2021, <a href="/wiki/Circuit_Zandvoort" title="Circuit Zandvoort">Circuit Zandvoort</a> returned to the F1 calendar as the <a href="/wiki/Dutch_Grand_Prix" title="Dutch Grand Prix">Dutch Grand Prix</a>, having last hosted a race in 1985.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>191<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Las_Vegas_Grand_Prix" title="Las Vegas Grand Prix">Las Vegas Grand Prix</a> entered the sport in 2023.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>192<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Cars_and_technology">Cars and technology</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=25" title="Edit section: Cars and technology"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_car" title="Formula One car">Formula One car</a>, <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_engines" title="Formula One engines">Formula One engines</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_tyres" title="Formula One tyres">Formula One tyres</a></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:Button_Spain_2009.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Button_Spain_2009.jpg/220px-Button_Spain_2009.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="134" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Button_Spain_2009.jpg/330px-Button_Spain_2009.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Button_Spain_2009.jpg/440px-Button_Spain_2009.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="972"></a><figcaption><a href="/wiki/Jenson_Button" title="Jenson Button">Jenson Button</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Brawn_BGP_001" title="Brawn BGP 001">Brawn BGP 001</a></figcaption></figure>
<p>Modern Formula One cars are <a href="/wiki/Mid-engine_design" title="Mid-engine design">mid-engined</a>, hybrid, semi-open cockpit, <a href="/wiki/Open-wheel_car" title="Open-wheel car">open-wheel</a> single-seaters. The <a href="/wiki/Chassis" title="Chassis">chassis</a> is made largely of <a href="/wiki/Carbon-fiber-reinforced_polymer" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon-fiber-reinforced polymer">carbon-fibre composites</a>, rendering it light but extremely stiff and strong. The whole car, including the driver but not fuel, weighs only 795 kg (1,753 lb) – the minimum weight set by the regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>193<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> If the construction of the car is lighter than the minimum, it can be <a href="/wiki/Ballast" title="Ballast">ballasted</a> up to add the necessary weight. The race teams take advantage of this by placing this ballast at the extreme bottom of the chassis, thereby locating the <a href="/wiki/Centre_of_gravity" class="mw-redirect" title="Centre of gravity">centre of gravity</a> as low as possible in order to improve handling and <a href="/wiki/Weight_transfer" title="Weight transfer">weight transfer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>194<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The cornering speed of Formula One cars is largely determined by the aerodynamic <a href="/wiki/Downforce" title="Downforce">downforce</a> that they generate, which pushes the car down onto the track. This is provided by "wings" mounted at the front and rear of the vehicle, and by <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_in_cars" class="mw-redirect" title="Ground effect in cars">ground effect</a> created by low air pressure under the flat bottom of the car. The aerodynamic design of the cars is very heavily constrained to limit performance. The previous generation of cars sported a large number of small winglets, "barge boards", and turning vanes designed to closely control the flow of the air over, under, and around the car.
</p><p>The other major factor controlling the cornering speed of the cars is the design of the <a href="/wiki/Tire" title="Tire">tyres</a>. From <a href="/wiki/1998_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="1998 Formula One World Championship">1998</a> to <a href="/wiki/2008_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2008 Formula One World Championship">2008</a>, the tyres in Formula One were not "<a href="/wiki/Slick_tyre" class="mw-redirect" title="Slick tyre">slicks</a>" (tyres with no tread pattern) as in most other circuit racing series. Instead, each tyre had four large circumferential grooves on its surface designed to limit the cornering speed of the cars.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>195<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Slick tyres returned to Formula One in the <a href="/wiki/2009_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2009 Formula One World Championship">2009</a> season. Suspension is <a href="/wiki/Double_wishbone_suspension" title="Double wishbone suspension">double wishbone</a> or <a href="/wiki/Multilink_suspension" class="mw-redirect" title="Multilink suspension">multilink</a> front and rear, with pushrod operated springs and <a href="/wiki/Shock_absorber" title="Shock absorber">dampers</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Chassis" title="Chassis">chassis</a> – one exception being that of the 2009 specification <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing" title="Red Bull Racing">Red Bull Racing</a> car (<a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_RB5" title="Red Bull RB5">RB5</a>) which used pullrod suspension at the rear, the first car to do so since the <a href="/wiki/Minardi" title="Minardi">Minardi</a> PS01 in 2001. <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Ferrari" title="Scuderia Ferrari">Ferrari</a> used a pullrod suspension at both the front and rear in their <a href="/wiki/2012_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2012 Formula One World Championship">2012</a> car.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>196<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Both Ferrari (F138) and McLaren (MP4-28) of the 2013 season used a pullrod suspension at both the front and the rear. In <a href="/wiki/2022_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2022 Formula One World Championship">2022</a>, <a href="/wiki/McLaren" title="McLaren">McLaren</a> (<a href="/wiki/McLaren_MCL36" title="McLaren MCL36">MCL36</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing" title="Red Bull Racing">Red Bull Racing</a> (<a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing_RB18" title="Red Bull Racing RB18">RB18</a>) switched to a pullrod front suspension and push rod rear suspension.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>197<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>198<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Reinforced_carbon-carbon" class="mw-redirect" title="Reinforced carbon-carbon">Carbon-carbon</a> <a href="/wiki/Disc_brakes" class="mw-redirect" title="Disc brakes">disc brakes</a> are used for reduced weight and increased frictional performance. These provide a very high level of braking performance and are usually the element that provokes the greatest reaction from drivers new to the formula. The carbon<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>199<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> material enhances the brakes by maintaining an effective performance<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>200<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> under extreme heat. To optimise this, the brakes feature 1,000 ventilation holes, ensuring for maximum performance and cooling.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/2022_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2022 Formula One World Championship">2022</a>, the technical regulations changed considerably in order to reduce the <a href="/wiki/Turbulence" title="Turbulence">turbulence</a> (commonly referred to as "dirty air") produced by the aerodynamics of the car. This includes a redesigned front and rear wing, larger wheels with a lower tyre profile, wheel covers, small winglets, the banning of barge boards, and the reintroduction of <a href="/wiki/Ground_effect_(cars)" title="Ground effect (cars)">Ground effect</a> downforce production. These have been changed to promote racing, meaning cars lose less downforce when following another car. It allows cars to follow another at a much closer distance, without extending the gap due to the turbulent air.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>201<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> (See <a href="/wiki/2022_Formula_One_World_Championship#Technical_regulations" title="2022 Formula One World Championship">2022 Formula One World Championship Technical regulations</a>)
</p><p>Formula One cars must have four wheels made of the same metallic material, which must be one of two <a href="/wiki/Magnesium_alloys" class="mw-redirect" title="Magnesium alloys">magnesium alloys</a> specified by the FIA.<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>202<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Magnesium_wheels" title="Magnesium wheels">Magnesium alloy wheels</a> made by <a href="/wiki/Forging" title="Forging">forging</a> are used to achieve maximum <a href="/wiki/Unsprung_weight" class="mw-redirect" title="Unsprung weight">unsprung rotating weight</a> reduction.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>203<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2022, the wheels are covered with "spec" (Standardised) Wheel Covers, the wheel diameter has increased from 13 inches to 18 inches (reducing the "tyre profile"), and small winglets have been placed over the front tyres.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>204<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg/220px-BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg/330px-BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b2/BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg/440px-BMW_Sauber_F1.06_engine.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1536"></a><figcaption>A <a href="/wiki/BMW_Sauber" class="mw-redirect" title="BMW Sauber">BMW Sauber</a> P86 V8 engine, which powered their <a href="/wiki/2006_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2006 Formula One World Championship">2006</a> F1.06</figcaption></figure>
<p>Starting with the 2014 Formula 1 season, the engines have changed from a 2.4-litre naturally aspirated V8 to turbocharged 1.6-litre V6 power-units.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>205<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These get a significant amount of their power from electric motors. In addition, they include a lot of energy recovery technology. Engines run on unleaded fuel closely resembling publicly available petrol.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>206<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The oil which lubricates and protects the engine from overheating is very similar in viscosity to water. The 2006 generation of engines spun up to 20,000 <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_per_minute" title="Revolutions per minute">rpm</a> and produced over 580 kW (780 bhp).<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>207<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> For <a href="/wiki/2007_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2007 Formula One World Championship">2007</a>, engines were restricted to 19,000 rpm with limited development areas allowed, following the engine specification freeze since the end of <a href="/wiki/2006_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2006 Formula One World Championship">2006</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>208<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> For the 2009 Formula One season the engines were further restricted to 18,000 rpm.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>209<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A wide variety of technologies – including active suspension<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>210<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> are banned under the current regulations. Despite this the current generation of cars can reach speeds in excess of 350 km/h (220 mph) at some circuits.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>211<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The highest straight line speed recorded during a Grand Prix was 372.6 km/h (231.5 mph), set by <a href="/wiki/Juan_Pablo_Montoya" title="Juan Pablo Montoya">Juan Pablo Montoya</a> during the <a href="/wiki/2005_Italian_Grand_Prix" title="2005 Italian Grand Prix">2005 Italian Grand Prix</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>212<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> During qualifying for the <a href="/wiki/2016_European_Grand_Prix#Qualifying" title="2016 European Grand Prix">2016 European Grand Prix</a>, <a href="/wiki/Valtteri_Bottas" title="Valtteri Bottas">Valtteri Bottas</a> set a record top speed of 378 km/h (234.9 mph).<sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>213<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> A <a href="/wiki/BAR_007" title="BAR 007">BAR-Honda Formula One car</a>, running with minimum downforce on a runway in the <a href="/wiki/Mojave_Desert" title="Mojave Desert">Mojave Desert</a> achieved a top speed of 415 km/h (258 mph) in 2006. According to Honda, the car fully met the FIA Formula One regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>214<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Even with the limitations on aerodynamics, at 160 km/h (99 mph) aerodynamically generated downforce is equal to the weight of the car, and the oft-repeated claim that Formula One cars create enough downforce to "drive on the ceiling", while possible in principle, has never been put to the test. Downforce of 2.5 times the car's weight can be achieved at full speed. The downforce means that the cars can achieve a lateral force with a magnitude of up to 3.5 times that of the force of gravity (3.5g) in cornering.<sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>215<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Consequently, the driver's head is pulled sideways with a force equivalent to the weight of 20 kg in corners. Such high lateral forces are enough to make breathing difficult and the drivers need supreme concentration and fitness to maintain their focus for the one to two hours that it takes to complete the race. A high-performance road car like the <a href="/wiki/Enzo_Ferrari_(car)" class="mw-redirect" title="Enzo Ferrari (car)">Enzo Ferrari</a> only achieves around 1g.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>216<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, each team may have no more than two cars available for use at any time.<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>217<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Each driver may use no more than four engines during a championship season unless they drive for more than one team. If more engines are used, they drop ten places on the starting grid of the event at which an additional engine is used. The only exception is where the engine is provided by a manufacturer or supplier taking part in its first championship season, in which case up to five may be used by a driver.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>218<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Each driver may use no more than one gearbox for six consecutive events; every unscheduled gearbox change requires the driver to drop five places on the grid unless they failed to finish the previous race due to reasons beyond the team's control.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>219<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, each driver is limited to three power units per season, before incurring grid penalties.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Revenue_and_profits">Revenue and profits</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=26" title="Edit section: Revenue and profits"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
