The reason given is: Needs update to account for the ban in private testing..<span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help update this article to reflect recent events or newly available information.</span>  <span class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">October 2024</span>)</i></span></div></td></tr></tbody></table><figure class="mw-halign-right" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_team_budget_split.svg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/F1_team_budget_split.svg/413px-F1_team_budget_split.svg.png" decoding="async" width="413" height="285" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/F1_team_budget_split.svg/620px-F1_team_budget_split.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/F1_team_budget_split.svg/826px-F1_team_budget_split.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="580" data-file-height="400"></a><figcaption>Estimated budget split of a Formula One team based on the <a href="/wiki/2006_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2006 Formula One World Championship">2006</a> season</figcaption></figure>
<p>In March 2007, <i><a href="/wiki/F1_Racing" class="mw-redirect" title="F1 Racing">F1 Racing</a></i> published its annual estimates of spending by Formula One teams.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>220<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The total spending of all eleven teams in 2006 was estimated at $2.9 billion US. This was broken down as follows: Toyota $418.5 million, Ferrari $406.5 m, McLaren $402 m, Honda $380.5 m, BMW Sauber $355 m, Renault $324 m, Red Bull $252 m, Williams $195.5 m, <a href="/wiki/Midland_F1_Racing" title="Midland F1 Racing">Midland F1/Spyker-MF1</a> $120 m, <a href="/wiki/Scuderia_Toro_Rosso" title="Scuderia Toro Rosso">Toro Rosso</a> $75 m, and <a href="/wiki/Super_Aguri_F1" title="Super Aguri F1">Super Aguri</a> $57 million.
</p><p>Costs vary greatly from team to team. Honda, Toyota, McLaren-Mercedes, and Ferrari were estimated to have spent approximately $200 million on engines in 2006, Renault spent approximately $125 million and Cosworth's 2006 V8 was developed for $15 million.<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>221<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In contrast to the 2006 season on which these figures are based, the 2007 sporting regulations banned all performance-related engine development.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>222<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Formula One teams pay entry fees of $500,000, plus $5,000 per point scored the previous year or $6,000 per point for the winner of the Constructors' Championship. Formula One drivers pay a <a href="/wiki/FIA_Super_Licence" title="FIA Super Licence">FIA Super Licence</a> fee, which in 2013 was €10,000 plus €1,000 per point.<sup id="cite_ref-aw_226-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-aw-226"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>223<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>There have been controversies with the way profits are shared among the teams. The smaller teams have complained that the profits are unevenly shared, favouring established top teams. In September 2015, <a href="/wiki/Force_India" title="Force India">Force India</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sauber" class="mw-redirect" title="Sauber">Sauber</a> officially lodged a complaint with the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> against Formula One questioning the governance and stating that the system of dividing revenues and determining the rules is unfair and unlawful.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>224<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The cost of building a brand-new permanent circuit can be up to hundreds of millions of dollars, while the cost of converting a public road, such as <a href="/wiki/Albert_Park_Circuit" title="Albert Park Circuit">Albert Park</a>, into a temporary circuit is much less. Permanent circuits, however, can generate revenue all year round from leasing the track for private races and other races, such as <a href="/wiki/MotoGP" class="mw-redirect" title="MotoGP">MotoGP</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Shanghai_International_Circuit" title="Shanghai International Circuit">Shanghai International Circuit</a> cost over $300 million<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>225<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Istanbul_Park" title="Istanbul Park">Istanbul Park</a> circuit cost $150 million to build.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>226<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A number of Formula One drivers earn the highest salary of any drivers in auto racing. The highest-paid driver in 2021 is Lewis Hamilton, who received $55 million in salary from Mercedes AMG Petronas F1 – a record for any driver.<sup id="cite_ref-Hamilton_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hamilton-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The very top Formula One drivers get paid more than <a href="/wiki/IndyCar" title="IndyCar">IndyCar</a> or <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> drivers; however, the earnings immediately fall off after the top three F1 drivers, and the majority of <a href="/wiki/NASCAR" title="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> racers will make more money than their F1 counterparts.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>228<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Most top IndyCar drivers are paid around a tenth of their Formula One counterparts.<sup id="cite_ref-Hamilton_230-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hamilton-230"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>227<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In the second quarter of 2020, Formula One reported a loss revenue of $122 million and an income of $24 million. This was a result of the delay of the racing championship start as a result of the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. The company grossed revenues of $620 million for the same quarter the previous year.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>229<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Cost_cap">Cost cap</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=27" title="Edit section: Cost cap"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Since the beginning of Formula 1 back in 1950, the sport's governing body has not had any regulations limiting the spending of a team. This has led to a pattern where teams with large budgets perform significantly better than their competitors and the gap has only continued to increase.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>230<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>For instance, in 2019, the richest teams such as Mercedes and Ferrari spent $420 million and $435 million respectively,<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>231<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> whereas teams such as Williams or Haas, only spent $125 million and $150 million respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>232<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This gap was widening by the season and disparities like this prompted the FIA to introduce a cost cap in February 2021.
</p><p>The FIA proposed the cost cap as a measure to reward engineering prowess over sheer expenditure. They did this in an effort to bridge the gap between the midfield teams and the teams challenging for the driver's and constructors' titles.
</p><p>The cap was $175 million in 2021, although was reduced further to $145 million in response to economic turmoil due to the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>. For 2022, the cost cap was further reduced to $140 million and in 2023 it fell to $135 million where it will remain for the 2024 and 2025 seasons.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>233<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>234<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The 2022 season served as a critical test for the effectiveness of the cost cap as it was the year the new regulations were introduced, allowing all teams to start from scratch and build a car that was independent of the previous years. Critics have argued that the cap might not be sufficient enough to close the gap in competition because it excluded certain expenses like driver salaries, compensation for the three highest paid-staff members, and marketing costs along with loopholes that allowed the likes of Adrian Newey's salary of Red Bull to be excluded from the cost cap.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>235<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> They also contended that established teams could exploit existing infrastructures and resources accumulated over years, thus maintaining their competitive edge despite the spending limits.
</p><p>However, an alternative perspective highlights that the cost cap encourages teams to maximise efficiency and foster innovation within their financial means. McLaren started the <a href="/wiki/2023_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2023 Formula One World Championship">2023 season</a> as the slowest car on the track, with their drivers finishing outside the points with <a href="/wiki/Lando_Norris" title="Lando Norris">Lando Norris</a> at P17 and <a href="/wiki/Oscar_Piastri" title="Oscar Piastri">Oscar Piastri</a> at P20. Seven months later, with the right upgrades, they managed to be the fastest car on the grid throughout qualifying and race pace. Facing budgetary constraints similar to their competitors, McLaren focused on strategic engineering upgrades and talent development. Their significant mid-season improvements led to notable on-track success, demonstrating that with clever resource management and engineering talent, teams can challenge the dominance of traditionally wealthier competitors.
</p><p>McLaren CEO <a href="/wiki/Zak_Brown" title="Zak Brown">Zak Brown</a> said that "the cap has been outstanding for the sport." He also went on to say that there is a feeling that at any point in the season, any team can challenge for a place it wasn't equipped to do so at the start of the season.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>236<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The critics have expressed that the impact of the cost cap suggests that engineering excellence and strategic ingenuity can indeed offset the advantages of larger budgets. By promoting a more balanced competitive environment, the cost cap has made Formula 1 more exciting for fans and more viable for teams.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Future">Future</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=28" title="Edit section: Future"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<figure class="mw-default-size" typeof="mw:File/Thumb"><a href="/wiki/File:F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg" class="mw-file-description"><img src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg/220px-F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="179" class="mw-file-element" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg/330px-F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg/440px-F1_yellow_flag_and_SC_sign.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1477" data-file-height="1204"></a><figcaption>A sign announcing that the <a href="/wiki/Safety_car" title="Safety car">safety car</a> (SC) is deployed</figcaption></figure>
<p>The expense of Formula One has seen the FIA and the Formula One Commission attempt to create new regulations to lower the costs for a team to compete in the sport.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>237<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Changes2016_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Changes2016-241"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>238<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Following their purchase of the commercial rights to the sport in 2017, <a href="/wiki/Liberty_Media" title="Liberty Media">Liberty Media</a> announced their vision for the future of Formula One at the <a href="/wiki/2018_Bahrain_Grand_Prix" title="2018 Bahrain Grand Prix">2018 Bahrain Grand Prix</a>. The proposal identified five key areas, including streamlining the governance of the sport, emphasising cost-effectiveness, maintaining the sport's relevance to road cars and encouraging new manufacturers to enter the championship whilst enabling them to be competitive.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>239<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>On 19 August 2020, it was announced that all 10 teams had signed the new Concorde Agreement.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>240<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This came into effect at the start of the 2021 season and changed how prize money and TV revenue is distributed.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>241<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Environmental_impact">Environmental impact</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=29" title="Edit section: Environmental impact"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Formula One has initiated a plan to become <a href="/wiki/Carbon_neutrality" class="mw-redirect" title="Carbon neutrality">carbon neutral</a> by 2030. By 2025, all events should become "sustainable", including eliminating single-use plastics and ensuring all waste is reused, recycled or composted.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>242<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>A report conducted by Formula One estimated that the series was responsible for 256,000 tonnes of <a href="/wiki/Carbon_dioxide" title="Carbon dioxide">carbon dioxide</a> emissions in the <a href="/wiki/2019_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2019 Formula One World Championship">2019 season</a>, finding that 45% of emissions were from logistics and only 0.7% were from emissions from the cars themselves.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>243<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>244<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In January 2020, FIA and Formula One signed the United Nations "Sports for Climate Action" framework. After the signing was announced, FIA President Jean Todt said: "As an international Federation comprising 244 members in 140 countries and the leader in motor sport and mobility development, we are fully committed to global environmental protection. The signing of this UN Sports for Climate Action Framework reinforces the momentum that has been growing in our Federation for many years. Since the introduction of the hybrid power unit in F1 to the creation of the Environment and Sustainability Commission, the entire FIA community has been investing time, energy and financial resources to the benefit of environmental innovations. We aim to inspire greater awareness and best practice in sustainability motor sport standards."<sup id="cite_ref-248" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-248"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>245<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>From the 2021–22 season, all cars will increase the bio-component of their fuel, using <a href="/wiki/Common_ethanol_fuel_mixtures" title="Common ethanol fuel mixtures">E10 fuel</a>, rather than the 5.75% of <a href="/wiki/Ethanol_fuel" title="Ethanol fuel">ethanol</a> currently used. This percentage is expected to grow again in the future.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>246<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In December 2020, the FIA claimed that it had developed a fuel with 100% sustainability, to be used in Formula One from either 2025 or 2026, when new engine regulations come into force.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>247<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Social_inequities">Social inequities</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=30" title="Edit section: Social inequities"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Prior to the beginning of the <a href="/wiki/2020_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2020 Formula One World Championship">2020 Formula One World Championship</a>, F1 announced and launched the #WeRaceAsOne initiative.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The initiative primarily focuses on visible displays of solidarity in the fight against racism on Grand Prix Weekends, as well as the creation of a Formula 1 Task Force that will "listen to people from across the paddock [...] and make conclusions on the actions required to improve the diversity and opportunity in Formula 1 at all levels".<sup id="cite_ref-:02_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-251"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>248<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The move spurs from the growing questions about racism and global inequalities perpetuated by the sport. The 70-year history of the World Championship has been dominated by European and white drivers, with the first (and only) black driver, <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton" title="Lewis Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a>, participating in the world championship since 2007.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>249<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In addition to organization-wide measures, individual teams have also acknowledged deficiencies in the sport's cultural and political activism. During the 2020 season, the <a href="/wiki/Mercedes-AMG_Petronas_F1_Team" class="mw-redirect" title="Mercedes-AMG Petronas F1 Team">Mercedes-AMG Petronas F1 Team</a> conducted a study of its racial composition and found that approximately 95% of its workforce was white.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>250<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Due to the results of the study, the team changed the car's livery to promote anti-racism messages and also launched the Accelerate 25 programme. The program vows that approximately 25% of all new hires to the team will come from underrepresented minorities in the sport until 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>251<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The 20 drivers on the grid have also stood in solidarity on multiple occasions in the fight against racism both on and off the track. Following the <a href="/wiki/Murder_of_George_Floyd" title="Murder of George Floyd">murder of George Floyd</a> in the summer of 2020, all twenty drivers wore "End Racism" shirts and took part in an organised anti-racism protest during the pre-race formalities.<sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>252<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In the year since, <a href="/wiki/Lewis_Hamilton" title="Lewis Hamilton">Lewis Hamilton</a> has remained vocal in his pre-race attire, with other drivers occasionally wearing change-demanding clothing.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>253<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Women_in_Formula_One">Women in Formula One</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=31" title="Edit section: Women in Formula One"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Since the creation of Formula One, in 1950, there have been five women to compete in a Grand Prix, and only one managed to score. The involvement of women in the Formula One paddock ranges from race engineers and strategists to media and communications personnel. With the release of the Netflix show, <a href="/wiki/Formula_1:_Drive_to_Survive" title="Formula 1: Drive to Survive">Drive to Survive</a>, the female viewership of the sport has risen. In 2019 20% of the total Formula One viewership was female, and by 2022 this number had increased to 40%.<sup id="cite_ref-257" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-257"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>254<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="F1_Academy">F1 Academy</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=32" title="Edit section: F1 Academy"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/F1_Academy" title="F1 Academy">F1 Academy</a>, created by Formula One in 2023, is the only female single-seater racing championship. Its inaugural championship was won by <a href="/wiki/Marta_Garc%C3%ADa_(racing_driver)" title="Marta García (racing driver)">Marta García</a> of <a href="/wiki/Prema_Racing" title="Prema Racing">Prema Racing</a>. The establishment of F1 Academy has attracted significant levels of attention to women in motorsport; <a href="/wiki/Netflix" title="Netflix">Netflix</a> has announced the release of a docuseries in 2025 about the academy. In addition to this companies such as <a href="/wiki/Tommy_Hilfiger_(company)" title="Tommy Hilfiger (company)">Tommy Hilfiger</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charlotte_Tilbury_Beauty" title="Charlotte Tilbury Beauty">Charlotte Tilbury</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>255<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Puma_(brand)" title="Puma (brand)">Puma</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull" title="Red Bull">Red Bull</a> have become sponsors of F1 Academy due to its increasing popularity.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>256<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Female_Formula_One_drivers">Female Formula One drivers</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=33" title="Edit section: Female Formula One drivers"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Maria_Teresa_de_Filippis" title="Maria Teresa de Filippis">Maria Teresa de Filippis</a> was the first female to compete in a Formula One Grand Prix at the 1958 Monaco Grand Prix. She competed in a total of five Grand Prix, racing under the Italian flag and has been hailed a pioneer of women in motorsport.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>257<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Lella_Lombardi" title="Lella Lombardi">Lella Lombardi</a> is the only female to place within the points at a Formula One Grand Prix. She competed in three seasons, entering seventeen races, and starting twelve. After finishing sixth in the <a href="/wiki/1975_Spanish_Grand_Prix" title="1975 Spanish Grand Prix">1975 Spanish Grand Prix</a>, Lombardi became the first and only female to score points during an official Formula Grand Prix. Due to the race not reaching full completion half points were awarded and Lombardi only gained .5 points.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>258<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Desir%C3%A9_Wilson" title="Desiré Wilson">Desiré Wilson</a> the only woman to win a Formula One race of any kind, winning the second round of the <a href="/wiki/1980_British_Formula_One_Championship" title="1980 British Formula One Championship">1980 Aurora AFX F1 Championship</a>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Race_engineers">Race engineers</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=34" title="Edit section: Race engineers"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hannah_Schmitz" title="Hannah Schmitz">Hannah Schmitz</a> currently holds the role of principal strategy engineer at <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing" title="Red Bull Racing">Red Bull Racing</a>. She has been with the team since 2009 and played a strong presence in its victories in 2021, 2022, and 2023. In 2023 Schmitz won the McLaren Applied Female Engineer of the Year Award winner for her role within <a href="/wiki/Red_Bull_Racing" title="Red Bull Racing">Red Bull Racing</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>259<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Team_principals">Team principals</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=35" title="Edit section: Team principals"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Susie_Wolff" title="Susie Wolff">Susie Wolff</a> is the current managing director of <a href="/wiki/F1_Academy" title="F1 Academy">F1 Academy</a>, however her presence within the Formula One paddock has lasted several decades. In the beginning of her career she was told to drive a pink car, although she was skeptical, Wolff obliged figuring that young girls would see the car and feel more inspired to begin racing.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>260<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2012 Wolff was a <a href="/wiki/Williams_Grand_Prix_Engineering" class="mw-redirect" title="Williams Grand Prix Engineering">Williams Grand Prix Engineering</a> development driver, during her four years at Williams, she competed in several free practice sessions for the team. After her time at Williams, Wolff became the team principal of Formula E team <a href="/wiki/Venturi_Racing" title="Venturi Racing">Venturi Racing</a>, and saw the team to their most successful season to date.
</p><p>Austrian <a href="/wiki/Monisha_Kaltenborn" title="Monisha Kaltenborn">Monisha Kaltenborn</a> became the sport's first ever female Team principal when she took over the role at <a href="/wiki/Sauber_Motorsport" title="Sauber Motorsport">Sauber Formula 1 Team</a> in 2010.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>261<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Media_and_presenters">Media and presenters</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=36" title="Edit section: Media and presenters"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Natalie_Pinkham" title="Natalie Pinkham">Natalie Pinkham</a> is a British television presenter and pit lane reporter for <a href="/wiki/Sky_Sports_F1" title="Sky Sports F1">Sky Sports F1</a>. She joined the television channel in 2012, and became the first woman commentator on British TV.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>262<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Naomi_Schiff" title="Naomi Schiff">Naomi Schiff</a> is a retired racing driver who is currently working as a television presenter for <a href="/wiki/Sky_Sports_F1" title="Sky Sports F1">Sky Sports F1</a>. After her retirement in 2020 she worked as the diversity and inclusion ambassador for the <a href="/wiki/W_Series_(championship)" title="W Series (championship)">W Series</a>, before joining the UK based television channel in 2022.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>263<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Media_coverage">Media coverage</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=37" title="Edit section: Media coverage"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_broadcasters" title="List of Formula One broadcasters">List of Formula One broadcasters</a></div>
<p>Formula One is broadcast live, or tape delayed in almost every country and territory and attracts one of the largest global television audiences. The <a href="/wiki/2008_Formula_One_World_Championship" title="2008 Formula One World Championship">2008 season</a> attracted a global audience of 600 million people per race.<sup id="cite_ref-paddocktalk.com_267-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-paddocktalk.com-267"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>264<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The cumulative television audience was calculated to be 54 billion for the 2001 season, broadcast to 200 territories.<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>265<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>During the early 1990s, Formula One Group created a number of trademarks, an official logo, an official TV graphics package and in 2003, an official website for the sport in an attempt to give it a corporate identity.
</p><p>TV stations all take what is known as the "World Feed", either produced historically by the "host broadcaster" or by <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_Management" class="mw-redirect" title="Formula One Management">Formula One Management</a> (FOM). The host broadcaster either had one feed for all, or two separate feeds – a feed for local viewers and a feed for international viewers. The one size fits all approach meant that there was bias to a certain team or driver during the event, which led to viewers missing out on more important action and incidents, while the two-feed approach meant that replays (for when returning from an ad break) and local bias action could be overlaid on the local feed while the international feed was left unaffected.
</p><p>The only station that differed from this set up was "DF1" (re-branded to "Premiere" then to "Sky Deutschland") – a German channel which offers all sessions live and interactive, with features such as the onboard and pit-lane channels. This service was purchased by Bernie Ecclestone at the end of 1996 and became F1 Digital Plus, which was made more widely available around Europe until the end of 2002, when the cost of the digital interactive service was thought too much.
</p><p>On 12 January 2011, F1 announced that it would adopt the <a href="/wiki/High-definition_television" title="High-definition television">HD</a> format for the 2011 season.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>266<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>It was announced on 29 July 2011, that <a href="/wiki/Sky_Sports" title="Sky Sports">Sky Sports</a> and the <a href="/wiki/BBC" title="BBC">BBC</a> would team up to show the races in F1 from 2012 to 2018. <a href="/wiki/BSkyB" class="mw-redirect" title="BSkyB">Sky</a> launched a dedicated channel, <a href="/wiki/Sky_Sports_F1" title="Sky Sports F1">Sky Sports F1</a> which covered all races live without commercial interruption as well as live practice and qualifying sessions, along with F1 programming, including interviews, archive action and magazine shows.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>267<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 2012 the BBC broadcast live coverage of half of the races in the season.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>268<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The BBC ended its television contract after the 2015 season, three years earlier than planned.<sup id="cite_ref-bbctoc4_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbctoc4-272"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>269<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The free-to-air TV rights were picked up by <a href="/wiki/Channel_4" title="Channel 4">Channel 4</a> until the end of the 2018 season.<sup id="cite_ref-C4F1_273-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-C4F1-273"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>270<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Sky Sports F1 coverage remained unaffected and <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_5_Live" title="BBC Radio 5 Live">BBC Radio 5 Live</a> and <a href="/wiki/BBC_Radio_5_Sports_Extra" title="BBC Radio 5 Sports Extra">5 Sports Extra</a> coverage was extended until 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>271<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> As of 2022, BBC Radio 5 Live and 5 Sports Extra has rights to such coverage until 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>272<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>While Sky Sports and Channel 4 are the two major broadcasters of Formula 1, other countries show Formula One races. Many use commentary from either Sky Sports or Channel 4. In most of Asia (excluding China), the two main broadcasters of Formula One includes the Fox network and Star Sports (in India). In the United States, <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> holds the official rights to broadcast the sport while <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> also holds free-to-air rights for some races under the <a href="/wiki/ESPN_on_ABC" title="ESPN on ABC">ESPN on ABC</a> banner. In Germany, Austria and Switzerland, the two main broadcasters are RTL Germany and n-TV. In China, there are multiple channels that broadcast Formula One which include CCTV, Tencent, Guangdong TV and Shanghai TV.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>273<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Currently in France, the only channel that broadcasts Formula One is the pay TV channel <a href="/wiki/Canal%2B_(French_TV_channel)" title="Canal+ (French TV channel)">Canal+</a>, having renewed its broadcasting rights until 2024.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>274<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>The official Formula One website has live timing charts that can be used during the race to follow the leaderboard in real time. An official application has been available for the <a href="/wiki/App_Store_(iOS)" class="mw-redirect" title="App Store (iOS)">Apple App Store</a> since 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>275<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and on <a href="/wiki/Google_Play" title="Google Play">Google Play</a> since 2011,<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>276<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> that shows users a real-time feed of driver positions, timing and commentary.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>277<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> On 26 November 2017 Formula One unveiled a new logo, which replaced the previous "flying one" in use since 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>278<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>In March 2018, FOM announced the launch of F1 TV, an <a href="/wiki/Over-the-top_media_service" title="Over-the-top media service">over-the-top streaming platform</a> that lets viewers watch multiple simultaneous video feeds and timing screens in addition to traditional directed race footage and commentary.<sup id="cite_ref-282" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-282"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>279<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In April 2024, FOM launched a <a href="/wiki/Free_ad-supported_streaming_television" title="Free ad-supported streaming television">free ad-supported streaming television</a> channel known as the Formula 1 Channel in the <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>, which shows classic Grands Prix, documentaries and analysis from past races.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>280<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading2"><h2 id="Distinction_between_Formula_One_and_World_Championship_races">Distinction between Formula One and World Championship races</h2><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=38" title="Edit section: Distinction between Formula One and World Championship races"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>Currently, the terms "Formula One race" and "World Championship race" are effectively synonymous. Since 1984, every Formula One race has counted towards the World Championship, and every World Championship race has been run to Formula One regulations. However, the two terms are not interchangeable.
</p>
<ul><li>The first Formula One race was held in 1946,<sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ESPN-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> whereas the World Championship did not start until 1950.<sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_284-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ESPN-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>In the 1950s and 1960s, there were many Formula One races that did not count for the World Championship;<sup id="cite_ref-silhouet_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhouet-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> in 1950, a total of twenty-two Formula One races were held, of which only six counted towards the World Championship.<sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_284-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ESPN-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The number of non-championship Formula One events decreased throughout the 1970s and 1980s, to the point where the last non-championship Formula One race was the <a href="/wiki/1983_Race_of_Champions" title="1983 Race of Champions">1983 Race of Champions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-silhouet_285-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhouet-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>The World Championship was not always exclusively composed of Formula One events:
<ul><li>The World Championship was originally established as the "World Championship for Drivers", i.e. without the term "Formula One" in the title. It only officially became the FIA Formula One World Championship in 1981.</li>
<li>From 1950 to 1960, the <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis_500" title="Indianapolis 500">Indianapolis 500</a> race counted towards the World Championship.<sup id="cite_ref-silhouet_285-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhouet-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This race was run to <a href="/wiki/American_Automobile_Association" title="American Automobile Association">American Automobile Association</a>, and later <a href="/wiki/United_States_Automobile_Club" class="mw-redirect" title="United States Automobile Club">United States Automobile Club</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_open-wheel_car_racing" title="American open-wheel car racing">Championship Car</a> regulations, rather than to Formula One regulations. Only one of the World Championship regulars, <a href="/wiki/Alberto_Ascari" title="Alberto Ascari">Alberto Ascari</a> in <a href="/wiki/1952_Indianapolis_500" title="1952 Indianapolis 500">1952</a>, started at Indianapolis during this period.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>283<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li>
<li>From 1952 to 1953, all races counting towards the World Championship (except the Indianapolis 500) were run to Formula Two regulations.<sup id="cite_ref-silhouet_285-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-silhouet-285"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>282<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> Formula One was not changed to Formula Two during this period; the Formula One regulations remained the same, and numerous non-championship Formula One races were staged during this time.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>284<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>285<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup></li></ul></li></ul>
<p>The distinction is most relevant when considering career summaries and all-time lists. For example, in the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Formula_One_drivers" title="List of Formula One drivers">List of Formula One drivers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clemente_Biondetti" title="Clemente Biondetti">Clemente Biondetti</a> is shown with a single race against his name. Biondetti actually competed in four Formula One races in 1950,<sup id="cite_ref-Biondetti_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Biondetti-289"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>286<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> but only one of these counted for the World Championship.
</p><p>In the earlier history of Formula One, many races took place outside the World Championship, and local championships run to Formula One regulations also occurred. These events often took place on circuits that were not always suitable for the World Championship and featured local cars and drivers as well as those competing in the championship.<sup id="cite_ref-LastnonchampF1_14-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LastnonchampF1-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="European_non-championship_racing">European non-championship racing</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=39" title="Edit section: European non-championship racing"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<p>In the early years of Formula One, before the world championship was established, there were around twenty races held from late Spring to early Autumn in Europe, although not all of these were considered significant. Most competitive cars came from Italy, particularly <a href="/wiki/Alfa_Romeo_in_Formula_One" title="Alfa Romeo in Formula One">Alfa Romeo</a>. After the start of the world championship, these non-championship races continued. In the 1950s and 1960s, there were many Formula One races which did not count for the World Championship; in <a href="/wiki/1950_Formula_One_season" title="1950 Formula One season">1950</a> a total of twenty-two Formula One races were held, of which only six counted towards the World Championship.<sup id="cite_ref-ESPN_284-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ESPN-284"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>281<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> In 1952 and 1953, when the world championship was run to Formula Two regulations, non-championship events were the only Formula One races that took place.
</p><p>Some races, particularly in the UK, including the <a href="/wiki/Race_of_Champions_(Brands_Hatch)" title="Race of Champions (Brands Hatch)">Race of Champions</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oulton_Park_International_Gold_Cup" title="Oulton Park International Gold Cup">Oulton Park International Gold Cup</a> and the <a href="/wiki/International_Trophy" class="mw-redirect" title="International Trophy">International Trophy</a>, were attended by the majority of the world championship contenders. Other smaller events were regularly held in locations not part of the championship, such as the <a href="/wiki/Syracuse_Grand_Prix" title="Syracuse Grand Prix">Syracuse</a> and <a href="/wiki/Danish_Grand_Prix" title="Danish Grand Prix">Danish</a> Grands Prix, although these only attracted a small amount of the championship teams and relied on private entries and lower Formula cars to make up the grid.<sup id="cite_ref-LastnonchampF1_14-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LastnonchampF1-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> These became less common through the 1970s and 1983 saw the last non-championship Formula One race; the <a href="/wiki/1983_Race_of_Champions" title="1983 Race of Champions">1983 Race of Champions</a> at Brands Hatch, won by reigning World Champion <a href="/wiki/Keke_Rosberg" title="Keke Rosberg">Keke Rosberg</a> in a Williams-Cosworth in a close fight with American <a href="/wiki/Danny_Sullivan" title="Danny Sullivan">Danny Sullivan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-LastnonchampF1_14-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LastnonchampF1-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="South_African_Formula_One_championship">South African Formula One championship</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=40" title="Edit section: South African Formula One championship"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/South_African_Formula_One_Championship" title="South African Formula One Championship">South African Formula One Championship</a></div>
<p>South Africa's flourishing domestic Formula One championship ran from 1960 through to 1975. The frontrunning cars in the series were recently retired from the world championship although there was also a healthy selection of locally built or modified machines.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="British_Formula_One_Championship">British Formula One Championship</h3><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Formula_One&action=edit&section=41" title="Edit section: British Formula One Championship"><span>edit</span></a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">Main article: <a href="/wiki/British_Formula_One_Championship" title="British Formula One Championship">British Formula One Championship</a></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Cosworth_DFV" title="Cosworth DFV">DFV</a> helped in making the UK domestic Formula One championship possible between 1978 and 1980. As in South Africa a decade before, second-hand cars from manufacturers like <a href="/wiki/Lotus_Cars" title="Lotus Cars">Lotus</a> and <a href="/wiki/Fittipaldi_Automotive" title="Fittipaldi Automotive">Fittipaldi Automotive</a> were the order of the day, although some, such as the March 781, were built specifically for the series. In 1980, the series saw <a href="/wiki/Formula_One_drivers_from_South_Africa" title="Formula One drivers from South Africa">South African</a> <a href="/wiki/Desir%C3%A9_Wilson" title="Desiré Wilson">Desiré Wilson</a> become the only woman to win a Formula One race when she triumphed at Brands Hatch in a <a href="/wiki/Walter_Wolf_Racing" title="Walter Wolf Racing">Wolf WR3</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>287<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
